contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.
Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

image.caption: Mary, circa 1920.

pageElements.text:
Mary Pickford

There were quite a few silent films starring women at the wheel. The first was An Auto Heroine, filmed in 1908 with a woman driver who was never identified. In 1912, Mary Pickford became the first star of an epic car chase, racing a car against a locomotive in D.W. Griffith’s A Beast at Bay. "She will do anything for the camera," Griffith said.
Mary's mother, Charlotte Smith, wasn’t so happy. She prayed alongside a racetrack during the filming.

image.caption: One of the first Ford Model A cars to be sold and delivered. Douglas gave it to Mary for Christmas.

pageElements.text: Mary owned many cars over the years, the most famous being a 1915 cream-colored Maxwell cabriolet, a gift from Maxwell in return for an endorsement. She also owned two Delage automobiles: a 1917 model and a 1922 model. (According to The Independent of St. Petersburg, Florida, the 1917 model cost $30,000 to make and only got three miles to the gallon! By 1938, when it appeared in the film The Shopworn Angel, it only made cameo appearances in movies.) Mary and her husband Douglas Fairbanks owned one of three custom-made 1923 Rolls-Royce Silver Ghosts. Her husband also bought her one of the first 1928 Ford Model A cars that rolled off the assembly line as a Christmas present. In later years, she owned a 1962 Rolls-Royce Silver Cloud II saloon.

Mary Pickford was more than "America's sweetheart"; she was a force behind the modernization of the movie business and a co-founder of the actor-owned United Artists studio and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, among others.

image.caption: Mabel Normand directed and starred in "Mabel at the Wheel" in 1914.

pageElements.text:
Mabel Normand

Mabel Normand directed and starred in Mabel At the Wheel in 1914, a year after she learned how to drive for The Speed Queen. She came up with the idea of mounting the camera to the front of the car to film close-ups of her driving. She had a fake rivalry with Marie Dressler that resulted in a race-off at Ascot Park in Santa Monica. Mabel brought a 1914 Stutz Bearcat and Marie brought a Fiat. Movie Pictorial magazine reported that “weather made a postponement necessary.” Normand also had a 1916 Mercer 22-72 Runabout with a dressing table and makeup mirror that folded into the driver’s side door.

Mabel’s love affair with cars was somewhat short lived. After she made Mickey in 1918, she began to rely on a chauffeur-driven car more and more as her movie career and health began to decline. She died of tuberculosis in 1930.

Collect the whole set!

#2: Alice Ramsey: first cross-country drive by women

contributors.bio:
I don’t understand people who dislike driving. I really don't. The freedom of getting behind the wheel of a car and just taking off can't be compared with anything else. You really feel that you’re in charge: in charge of the car, in charge of the road, and in charge of your life. Why on earth would you want someone else to drive you around when you could do it yourself? It’s so liberating! Obviously, I love driving. I suppose that isn't a particularly original statement for a Detroit native, but it's true. I was a little late getting my driver's license because of that pesky parallel parking, but once I got it, nothing could stop me. It doesn't matter if I have to chauffeur my grandmother to the bank less than a block from our house or drive across town. If I have my green Chrysler LHS--affectionately christened "Betsy" by my mother--and some gas in the tank, and if I am somehow able to avoid getting pulled over for driving just a little too fast, I'm good to go.

Since I graduated from the University of Michigan, in April 2012, Betsy has taken me everywhere. She has been my steadfast companion on trips to buy more supplies for various sewing projects, leisurely drives along Jefferson/Lakeshore Drive in Grosse Pointe Shores, Michigan, and frequent jaunts to the bookstore to buy yet another copy of Hamlet, a 500-plus-page book on Elizabeth I, or a good book on British history that isn’t as dry as a piece of chalk…And, yes, there is a little bit of theme there. Not only am I a bibliophile, but I’m also a self-proclaimed Anglophile who loves Shakespeare and Elizabethan verse and one day plans to see the Houses of Parliament, visit the Tower of London, and, perhaps most important, eat real fish and chips. If only I could drive Betsy "across the pond…"

pageElements.text: There will be a day in every car owner’s life when the dreaded fender bender or accident with a wild animal will occur. Not only are you shaken up from the impact, but now you have to worry about insurance and where you’ll take your car for collision repairs.

If you have a trusted mechanic or dealership, deciding where to take your car for repairs may not be a problem. But for those who are looking for a body shop they can trust, going with one that is part of a franchise network is worth considering rather than taking your chances with a local mom-and-pop operation.
Carstar is one such franchise network composed of more than 400 independently owned and operated stores in thirty-one states and ten Canadian provinces.

Carstar CEO David Byers says his company takes on existing independent repair shops, consolidating them under the Carstar franchise umbrella. That's what is known as "conversion franchising." Conversion franchising allows independent shop owners to remain so, but also provides them with the support of a centralized management team; training in collision repair, financial management, and customer service; and the ability to work with a larger number of insurance companies via Carstar’s insurance staff liaisons.
The advantage for you, the customer, is that you are still dealing with an independently run business, but one with the advantages of a larger organizational structure:

1. A franchised shop is part of a brand. This probably seems like a real no-brainer, but think about it for a few minutes. A trustworthy mechanic can be as rare as independent garages are plentiful. If you’re looking for an independent repair shop and think you have reason to be suspicious, you have a whole host of ways to check that the facility you choose provides high-quality service. But with a franchised shop, you don’t have to go through all of that work. Byers says that if you choose a known brand to service your car, there are more ways to be assured of the quality of work you’ll be receiving.

By calling a toll-free number or chatting online with a service representative, Carstar provides accident assistance twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. In the event of an accident, Carstar can call your insurance company and have your vehicle towed to begin the repair process and will even call a family member or friend at your request. The company employs certified technicians who receive ongoing training in customer service practices, working with new vehicle materials and technologies like carbon fiber and waterborne paint, and using new repair processes. Carstar also performs a fifty-point interior and exterior quality inspection and a test drive before returning your car to you and offers detailing work to return the car to like-new condition.

2. Carstar works with all vehicle makes and models and all insurance companies. If your car is new or still under warranty, it makes the most sense to take it to the dealership to be repaired by company-trained mechanics. However, for someone like me who drives a thirteen-year-old car, going to the dealership where my great-uncle purchased the car makes neither financial nor logistical sense (both my great-uncle and the dealership are about three hours away from my home). According to Byers, neither the age of the vehicle nor the make or model will affect Carstar technicians' abilities to perform auto body repairs. Carstar technicians are trained to work on all cars, regardless of their age or nation of origin. To make the repair process smoother for the customer, Carstar also retains a team of insurance experts who coordinate vehicle repair with more than eighty insurance carriers, including well-known ones such as Allstate, Farmers Insurance Group, Geico, Liberty Mutual, Nationwide, and Progressive.

3. Your car is always safe and never really out of your sight. A universal worry when a car enters a shop for collision repair is whether it’s safe and whether it's actually being worked on. In most situations, you have no way to assure yourself that the car is being repaired. Something that you won’t find at the usual collision repair facility is what Byers's company calls Carstar Vision. This lets you get a look at your car online from the beginning to the end of the repair process. You log in and can view photos of the progress of your vehicle repair. You can also send questions or comments to the mechanic and receive answers. Carstar also sends e-mail updates concerning the car’s repair status.

4. Your repair comes with a warranty. Once your car has been fixed, something could go wrong, and back to the shop you’ll go. Carstar offers a nationwide five-year warranty that covers labor and materials. You can return the car to the same location or any other Carstar store to make things right. The warranty is guaranteed as long as the repaired car remains in your possession but is not transferable if ownership of the vehicle changes hands.

5. Financing is available. Carstar also allows you to pay off repair charges in monthly installments with financing through its CarCareONE credit card. The interest rate, currently over 28 percent, is undesirable, but if you were going to use a high-interest credit card anyway, it's an option to consider.

pageElements.text: We’ve all been there: driving down a dark country road minding our own business, when we crest a hill and are suddenly blinded by an oncoming car’s high beams, the driver too slow or too inconsiderate to turn them off in time to spare us. It’s annoying, sure, but it’s a problem we’re stuck with, right? Wrong. Volvo is here to save the day.

Volvo introduced its refreshed-for-2014 S60, V60, and XC60 models at the recent Geneva Auto Show and the cars are packed with new technology, including Volvo’s active high beam control system, which automatically adjusts the car’s high beams to spare oncoming drivers from the glare.

The technology works by using information from the camera already installed near the rearview mirror for detection and automatic braking. When the camera spots a car or motorcycle in the path of the high beams, it sends that information to a projector module mechanism in the headlamp, which uses small pieces of metal to shade out only the necessary parts of the high beams, leaving fellow drivers unperturbed and maintaining your clear view of the road ahead. Volvo says the technology is so accurate that it can shade out the correct portion of the headlights with only a 1.5-degree margin.

Volvo hopes the technology will keep drivers safer by allowing them to spot and avoid vulnerable road users like pedestrians, cyclists, and animals even in situations when they would normally have to turn off the brights and decrease visibility temporarily.
The high beams come as part of the $2,100 technology package on the S60, S80, XC60, and XC70. The active high beam control system will be available on the S60, V60, and XC60 this spring.

pageElements.text: Three silent-film stars, Mae Murray, Ormi Hawley, and Mary Anderson, all had reputations as skilled mechanics who worked on their own cars, and that was in the early years of the twentieth century. Florence Lawrence was not only a popular silent-film actress but an inventor who was decades ahead of her time.

Mae Murray, Ormi Hawley, and Mary Anderson

It's said that Mae may have been the inspiration for the cult-film classic Sunset Boulevard. By that it's meant that she was a diva, and later a troubled soul, long beyond the years when she was on the screen. She's also said to have been an enthusiastic driver who did her own repairs. That is worthy of respect, especially since she was lampooned in a satirical article in Photoplay magazine about her free-spirited driving style.

Ormi Hawley, too, was a skilled mechanic as well as an actress who appeared in more than 300 films, and "Sunshine" Mary Anderson, a lesser-known actress whose career lasted from 1914 to 1923, was quoted as saying she had just as much fun repairing as driving her car.

Florence Lawrence: From Baby Flo to Inventor

Born in 1886, Florence Lawrence started out in life as a child curiosity, billed on the vaudeville stage as Baby Flo, the Child Wonder Whistler. As she grew up, she became successful film actress with the company that was the precursor to Universal Pictures and spent some of that mad money on her own car in 1913. History doesn't record what kind.

Florence went beyond enjoying the car and considered ways of improving it. She came up with two things that nowadays we'd consider indispensable: the turn signal and the brake light. First was what she called an "auto-signaling arm" for the rear fender, an early turn signal using flags that were raised and lowered by electric push buttons. Next, she came up with the ancestor of the high-mounted brake light: when you stepped on the brake, a sign reading "stop" went up automatically from the back bumper. She never patented either invention, though. Her mother, Charlotte Bridgwood, invented and patented the windshield wiper in 1917 but didn't pursue its commercial production.
Florence was seriously burned in a studio fire in 1915, and she also suffered from a bone-marrow disease. Perhaps these afflictions contributed to her suicide, by poisoning, in 1938.

She once commented: "A car to me is something that is almost human," she said, "something that responds to kindness and understanding and care, just as people do." A sad end to someone who so clearly was our kind of gal.

pageElements.text: What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.
Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

Gloria Swanson

In 1916, movie star Gloria Swanson was a mere seventeen years old, and her fiance, Wallace Beery, was teaching her to drive. She just loved it and compared it to the thrill she got horseback riding as a kid. She describes how she came to make the film The Danger Girl for Keystone:

"One morning when I was driving to work, I found myself answering some command from deep inside me and started putting on speed until I heard Wally screaming in the seat beside me. I tore past the Keystone gates and almost missed the turn into our lot across the street. I roared up to the bungalow, jumped on the brake, and stopped on a dime.

"When the dust settled, half a dozen people ran out of the building. They couldn’t believe it was Baby Gloria behind the wheel. They hadn’t had such a shock since they first saw me smoke a cigarette." Someone joked that it would be a funny way to start a movie, and within the week, a rough script was ready.

From the Sublime Bentley to the Downmarket Toyota

Like many other Hollywood actors of her generation, Gloria was a wealthy woman and had money to burn, which she spent with abandon on clothes, houses, and lavish cars. Gloria owned a 1929 Model A Ford station wagon, a 1920s-era Leach, a 1949 Rolls-Royce Silver Wraith, a 1963 Bentley S3, a 1965 Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow III, a 1970 Vauxhall Viva, and a 1970 Toyota Corona Mark II, which was a replacement for one of her chauffeur-driven Rolls-Royce cars. Her most famous car was a Lancia upholstered with leopard skins, which likely inspired the leopard-upholstered 1930 Isotta-Fraschini that belonged to her most famous character, Norma Desmond, in the 1950 classic Sunset Boulevard.

images.caption: Gloria Swanson (1899-1983) with an exotic-looking custom Leach, built in Los Angeles in the 1920s. The car is said to have been powered by a big six-cylinder engine designed by Harry Miller.
Gloria's first husband, Wallace Beery, taught her how to drive before they were married, which eventually led to making the film "The Danger Girl."
Gloria had chauffeur-driven cars but was known to drive herself with the chauffeur sitting next to her.
The car that co-starred in "Sunset Boulevard" was a 1930 Isotta-Fraschini. It once belonged to American socialite Peggy Hopkins Joyce, who received it from automobile magnate Walter Chrysler.

Pearl White, The Original Pauline

My patron saint of adventure is Pearl White, the star of the original Perils of Pauline series in 1914. She liked to get a new car every six months but was most famous for a 1915 yellow Stutz Bearcat she used to tear up the roads around Ithaca, New York. She was fined five dollars for speeding in nearby Trumansburg. She gave the justice of the peace ten dollars because, she said, "I'm leaving your goddamned town as fast as I came in."

Pearl was said to have done her own stunts for the Pauline series, sustaining injuries that plagued her throughout her life. She also drove a racing car through Paris and around the countryside for her last film, Terror, filmed in 1923. It was a big hit in France at a time when it wasn't as common for women over there to drive.

title: Jamie Little's Car Care Book
promoTeaserSmall: ESPN reporter co-authors a manual for those of us who love cars but don't totally get how they work.
promoTeaser: ESPN reporter co-authors a manual for those of us who love cars but don't totally get how they work.
metaTitle: A Car Care Book from ESPN's Jamie Little - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Read our interview with ESPN's motorsports reporter Jamie Little, who talks about her new co-authored book, Essential Car Care for Women. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: On a rainy Friday night in Las Vegas, Jamie Little sits at a table in a casino's sports bar, where buckets are catching drips from the roof. Tomorrow she will do an ESPN telecast from the nearby speedway, but now she's signing copies of Essential Car Care for Women, which she co-authored with Danielle McCormick.

For the occasion, Little has dressed stylishly in a canary jacket and cobalt jeans, complemented by chunky jewelry. Eighteen hours from now, she’ll be reporting from the clamor and stench of the pits, all delicacy and flair being surrendered to flame-retardant ESPN overalls and cumbersome headphones.
The book signing is another kind of action, and she appears to love it. “How’re you guys doing?” she says, pen at the ready in her slender left hand. “What’s your name?”
Fans in town for the NASCAR race ask her to pose with them for photos. Then they walk over by the slot machines and look at the inscription. “I just met a star!” one man says.
The establishment’s manager picks up a microphone to remind patrons not to miss out. “That’s ESPN reporter Jamie Little signing her book next to the lobster tank,” he says. “Ten dollars for a copy!”

The next morning we meet at Las Vegas Motor Speedway, and Little explains how co-author Danielle McCormick approached her about collaborating. It was to be a more comprehensive version of a car care book McCormick had written that was published in Great Britain. Their book takes the viewpoint that not every woman who has a car "also has a reliable man in her life."
As Little writes in her introduction, "It’s all just a matter of education, and it’s time for a change, ladies!"

From a basic lexicon, sort of a Devil's Dictionary of automotive lingo, to the process of chaining up tires for winter driving in the mountains, Essential Car Care for Women is worthy of Little's claim that it belongs in the glove box along with the owners manual. You don't have to be a woman to benefit from its clear and basic instruction, either.

Don't let it be your only reference material, though, and take the text with a grain of salt: the contention that flat tires come from deflated inner tubes (on page 21) overlooks the fact that tubeless tires became standard equipment in 1955. Possibly it's an error introduced when that part of the book was translated from British to American English, although McCormick points out that vintage cars' tires might still contain tubes.

Never mind, because this is a "visual book," as Little reminds us, and the pictures really do tell the story. It's especially well designed, with good illustrations and how-to photos in a style reminiscent of This Old House. Little demonstrates how to change a tire, use jumper cables on a dead battery, and even keep your poise when managing the aftermath of a fender bender. The book is very helpful for readers who want to understand the basics of how their car works but have been afraid to ask. Case in point: the clear, illustrated explanation of the habits of a four-stroke engine. It takes you from intake to exhaust and demystifies what happens inside those cylinders to make your car go. With plenty of other similarly helpful explanations, Essential Car Care for Women will give you more confidence when talking about and dealing with cars.

The Mitsubishi Eclipse convertible seen in the photos was a rental, specifically chosen because it's "kind of girly," she says. But there was another factor. "Because I cover NASCAR, I didn't want it to be any of the brands that compete [on the tracks], because I don't want to play favorites." Unlike Toyota, Mitsubishi never made it to NASCAR.

Beyond the most practical aspects of car care, the books larger usefulness lies in the way it gets you thinking about cars, which is something Little has done a lot of since joining ESPN in 1998. She speaks of the "adrenaline rush" of giving live updates from the pits and interviewing the winning driver in Victory Lane.

Her dedication is so profound that in 2012 she worked until she was thirty-six weeks pregnant. Her son, Carter, now seven months old, recognizes his mother's voice on TV and loves the hum of racing, a taste Little says was acquired in utero. "I may have created a monster. He's going to love cars, for sure."

When Little was a girl, she says, she was mesmerized by anything that "made noise and went fast." Her enthusiasm led her to this point. She admits that sometimes she finds herself thinking about being the first woman in the broadcast booth calling the play-by-play for major races.

Then she always reconsiders, thinking of the irresistible action on her favorite tracks at Bristol, Tennessee, and Talladega, Alabama. "The great thing about my job is being in the middle of it. I'm where everybody wants to be. I can touch the tires and smell the gas. Being in a booth, to me, is just kind of stale."
So when you look up from the pages of Essential Car Care for Women, keep watching for Little’s familiar ponytail and insulated fire suit as she produces more stories from pit road.
Essential Car Care for Women comes out in April, priced at $16, from the woman-oriented publisher Seal Press.

metaTitle: Look Who's Driving - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Look Who's Driving - Read about my fears and concerns when my teen daughter got her learner's permit. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: The sweet six-year-old girl that you see in this photo is now sixteen and is counting down the days until she can drive without any supervision. You know, life really begins when you can pull out of the driveway without a parent. At least, it did for me, but that's another story. She is the perfect daughter in almost every way, but her attention span is shorter than that of Chuy from Chelsea Lately. The nightly ritual of homework is filled with constant nagging to focus. One by one, I have to remind her: turn off your phone, no YouTube, no Facebook, turn down the music. Once she is in a car alone, who is going to keep her focused? The consequences are much higher than when she does a sloppy job on a homework assignment.

Michigan has a graduated license process for anyone under eighteen. My daughter has completed the first segment, which included twenty four hours of class time, six hours of driving with the school's instructors, and a state-required written exam. I was horrified when she barely passed the test and the driving school didn't even go over the questions that she had missed. I was the obnoxious mom who asked the instructor to stay and help her review her mistakes. Seriously, this shit matters.

On a Scale of One to Ten

The next day, we were off to the Secretary of State to get her passport to freedom. During this phase, she will have a permit but is required to spend fifty hours of supervised driving with an adult driver who is over twenty-one. I asked her: On a scale of one to ten, with ten being an expert driver, where does she think she stands. "Prolly an eight," she responded.

I like the confidence, but if Jeff Gordon is a ten, I'm thinking I'm a six and she is a one. But I have to remember that when she goes to the doctor for anything, she always gives her pain level as a ten.

The Scariest Hour

My husband decided to have her drive that very night to Bloomfield Hills, a fifty-minute drive with tricky highway exchanges and four miles on uber-busy Orchard Lake Road at night. Quick reminder: she had driven a total of six hours. She confidently slipped into the driver's seat and began what I consider to be the scariest hour of my life. She is actually a very smooth driver but is quite timid. She also drives way far to the right in her lane, and takes very wide sweeping turns. My husband sat in the front and guided her in a very laid-back manner, while every now and then I would interject in a shrill, terrified voice. I finally closed my eyes and pretended I was on a ride at Disneyland.

Gathering of the Helicopter Parents

Several days later, I found an e-mail in my in box asking me to take part in a focus group for parents of students who have just begun this supervised driving time with their teens. My helicopter had landed! I responded immediately: Yes, please.

I surmised that the participants would likely be other helis who were taking the job of supervisor just as seriously as I was. When I arrived, I learned that we were taking part in a study to create a parent coaching guide. The focus group was conducted by the Young Driver Behavior and Injury Prevention at the University of Michigan's Transportation Research Institute.
They had me at Injury Prevention.

As they rolled out the various sections that they would be including in the guide, I realized that we had gone from zero to sixty with our daughter waaaay too fast. Their first step involves practicing in an empty parking lot and checking off skills in an organized manner, not hopping in the car and immediately heading for the nearest heavily congested highway. Brilliant.

The facilitators explained that this supervised driving period offers a unique opportunity to reduce teen drivers' risk of being in a crash. Other parent guides exist, but few focus on the actual practice of critical driving skills, and none are evidence based. This parent coaching guide is intended to help parents use effective communication, coaching techniques, and practice exercises with their teen, which will let us coach them in acquiring skills that are critical to safety.
Now these people were talking my language.

Group Therapy for Parents of Teen Drivers

As we worked our way through the steps, the group shared their experiences as supervisors. One woman's daughter has had her license for eight months, but they have only been out twice because they are both terrified. One man shared how he can't do it, either, so his friends and relatives help out. It was a bit of a group therapy session where we commiserated about how ill-equipped we all feel.

When I shared the story of my daughter's drive to Bloomfield the night she got her permit, the group went silent. Their reactions reminded me of the look on my daughter's face late one night at a family gathering when all of her cousins went to put on their jammies and I had forgotten to bring hers. Bad mom!

Jean Knows Driving

The University of Michigan study results will not be available in time to help us, but I did take away the idea to build my daughter's skills slowly. It is not going to make her happy, but we are going to go back to the empty parking lot and make sure she has nailed the basics.

I have asked Jean to step in and give her a crash (not literally) course in the finer points of driving. Jean promised to squeeze her in this spring. Stand by to read all about the Jean master classes! pageElements.text: What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.
Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

The Talking "It" Girl

The transition to talkies at the end of the 1920s was also the end of the devil-may-care Jazz Age. As the Roaring Twenties wound down, so did the careers of so many stars who couldn't make the transition.

Bad little girl Clara Bow, Hollywood's "It" girl, loved fast cars and had enormous influence on the very sort of woman she portrayed on the screen: the working girl. She came from horrendous poverty, was raised in a tenement slum, and convinced her father to pay for a photo shoot to enter a Fame and Fortune contest for a movie role in Beyond the Rainbow, which she won. Her mother, a prostitute, tried to kill her several times and ended up in a mental hospital. At sixteen years old, Clara was raped by her alcoholic father, whom she still tried to care for and even allowed to live with her until his death in the 1950s.

As Mark Patrick of the Revs Institute for Automotive Research in Naples, Florida, said of the photo of Clara with the flashiest car of the day, Harley Earl's 1927 LaSalle, "What kind of nice Twenties girl buys a newly introduced, flashy car like a LaSalle? She was an It girl in an It car. The LaSalle was fast and flashy, just the car for a fast and flashy actress. In vibrant colors, it was the car for wealthy frat boys with low morals, prohibition gangsters and their broads, and silent-screen flapper actresses."

Clara was very talented, if somewhat crude by Hollywood standards. Clara managed to slide in under the few standards Hollywood had, which is, perhaps, the correct choice of words in the case of the girl who, it was rumored, slept with the entire University of Southern California football team and who was sued for alienation of affections by the wife of a doctor. The reports and accusations got worse and Clara was too fragile to handle them. The "dese"s and "dose"s of her heavy Brooklyn accent and her nervous stutter didn't help her case for making it into the talkies. Paramount dropped her in 1931, but she made two films after that before permanently retiring, saying, "I don't wanna be remembered as somebody who couldn't do nothin' but take her clothes off."

She had some semblance of a normal life but was eventually diagnosed with schizophrenia in 1949, endured horrible shock treatments, and died of a heart attack in 1965.  I prefer to remember her by something she said from her sanitarium in 1951: "We had individuality. We did as we pleased. I'd whiz down Sunset Boulevard in my open Kissel with several chow dogs to match my hair. Today, they're more sensible and end up with better health. But we had more fun."

pageElements.text:
2013 Mercedes-Benz G63 AMG

Vital Stats

Base price: $135,205 (includes destination)
This car's price: $137,505 (includes destination and $2,300 designo Mystic Brown exterior paint color)
EPA fuel economy: 12 mpg city/14 mpg highway (with 4Matic permanent all-wheel drive, 5.5-liter biturbo V-8, seven-speed automatic transmission)
Safety features: Parktronic electronic parking aid, Distronic Plus adaptive cruise control, blind spot assist, electronic stability control (ESP), brake assist, adaptive brake technology
Tech features: Bluetooth connectivity with audio streaming, Comand system with navigation, iPod/MP3 interface, Harman Kardon Logic7 surround sound, Mbrace2 telematics
Chief competitors: Cadillac Escalade Hybrid, BMW X6M

Key Points

Do you love it or hate it? The Gelandewagen is a cult classic but has also been lampooned as "the most awesomely ridiculous vehicle you can buy today."
Well, it did start out as a military machine. Today, though, it's hand built and goes to seekers of high-end luxury and distinctiveness.
There's an incredible list of luxury features on board: a heated windshield, Harman Kardon surround sound, and mbrace2, designed to bring the Internet to the dashboard with features like around-the-clock concierge services and a "real-life co-pilot" who provides turn-by-turn directions. Take that, Siri!
Let's not forget the luxury Neck-Pro head restraints, which are connected to an electronic control unit that can sense a rear-end collision about to happen and move the head restraints up and forward in the milliseconds before impact.
Safety features bring the G63 about as close to autonomous driving as we see in a 2013 production vehicle.
544-horsepower twin-turbo engine is useful in getting this 5,800-pound vehicle from 0 to 60 mph in 5.2 seconds.
The only EPA-rated car with worse fuel economy is the Bugatti Veyron.
The only vehicle you can buy that is this crazily distinctive is...can't think of a thing.

Fay Wray

Maybe good girl Fay Wray's choice of the more conservative, yet pretty damn powerful 1927 Packard coupe is a hint to why her career was able to make the leap to talkies. In 1929, after only a few struggling years in silent films and one year after her brother escaped from a mental institution and committed suicide by jumping in front of a streetcar, Fay was canceled by Paramount but came back with a roar. She made eleven movies in 1933, the bulk of which were horror films like Enemies of Society, Doctor X, and The Vampire Bat. King Kong, named one of the 100 greatest films of all time, was one of those horror films, and it made her famous. She made another eleven movies in 1934 and gradually wound down from there.

Fay drove a car past the age of ninety and died in her sleep a month before her ninety-seventh birthday, just before she was to appear in Peter Jackson's remake of King Kong. The lights on the Empire State Building were dimmed in her honor for fifteen minutes a few days after her death.

title: Eating in the Car: Our Top Picks
promoTitle: Eating in the Car: Our Top Picks
promoTeaserSmall: Whether on a long trip or pressed for time, food happens in the car. Here's how we make it work.
promoTeaser: Whether on a long trip or pressed for time, food happens in the car. Here's how we make it work.
metaTitle: Eating in the Car: Our Top Picks - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Eating in the Car: Our Top Picks. Read the JeanKnowsCars.com staff's picks for best food to eat in the car. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: There are those who ban eating in their vehicles on the grounds that eating is messy, germy, and simply not a classy thing to do in the car. To those tasteful individuals, I say: Oh, please. Having snacks in the car makes a long drive more amusing, comforting, and sociable.  And there isn't a parent out there who hasn't needed to feed kids on the move because there wasn't enough time in the day.
If you carry healthy snacks that you pack ahead of time, over the long term you might be saving millions of calories and lots of cash that you might have spent on drive-through junk food.
Or, look at it another way: a drive can be made a lot more fun if you do hit the drive-through or the gas station shop for the kind of fun food you wouldn't deign to touch under normal circumstances.
I asked everybody here at Jean Knows Cars to share their favorite in-car food choices. But first, here are the three rules to follow when you're eating in the car.

image.caption: Gabrielle George keeps her eyes on the road and her hands on the wheel.

pageElements.text:
1. Don't let it be a distraction.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration identifies eating while driving as one of the major distracted-driving behaviors. Don't take your eyes off the road to deal with food, and whenever possible, eat only while you're a passenger or the car is not moving. Don't be the slob careening down the expressway at 80 mph with a cheeseburger in one hand and a soda in the other.

image.caption: Observe the neatness of videographer Scott Allen.

pageElements.text:
2. Don't let it trash your car.

It's not difficult to bring along napkins or, my personal favorite, a kitchen towel to put on your lap. It's even easier to have a plastic bag to store the trash and scraps from in-car dining. Wet wipes make life easier when children are the ones eating in the car; bring some of those.

3. Don't make it a substitute for real meals.

I once read a memorable article about a bulimic woman who said the only two places she ever ate were in bed and in the car. That's extreme, but it's easy (especially on a road trip) to go too far with the drive-through and picnic behavior. Stop at a roadside restaurant, or make your snacks light so you can get home and have a real dinner at the table.

My Picks

Keep in mind, I have been transporting my four kids in a minivan for two decades now, so no highbrow food choices for me. My standby is a cooler filled with juice, water bottles, peanut-butter-and-jelly sandwiches, crackers, and fruit for meals. I like it when everybody can have a snack when they want one, which cuts way down on crankiness. On road trips, I supplement by letting them get sunflower seeds, soda, chips, and Sour Patch Kids at gas stations. I am also perfectly willing to live off drive-through food for short periods. My favorite crunchy snack for everybody in the family is Bugles, because they satisfy salt cravings without being too greasy or crumbly.

As for myself, I am content if I have a never-ending supply of coffee and lots of chewing gum. For some reason, as long as I can chew gum, I can be alert and content while driving. My number-one banned substance is any kind of energy drink or supplement. If I'm too tired to perk up from coffee, I'm ready to stop driving.

image.caption: Jean Jennings tries to keep it healthy.

pageElements.text:
Jean Jennings's Picks

I plan ahead with a list of healthy food choices in the car: a bag of apples, oranges, bottles of water, baby carrots, Twizzlers (a giant bag), raw walnuts, pecans, almonds, and Brazil nuts mixed with dried cherries and cranberries.

I learned how to eat on road trips by doing the One Lap of America race three times. When it's a long road trip where we plan to spend some real hours in the car, we make it a point to eat one light meal, and we get out of the car and sit at a table to do it. We look for something like a Bob Evans, because they have really great salads and a healthy menu.

Actually what I really like in the car are gumdrops, jellybeans, M&M Peanuts, and full-fat Wheat Thins, but I'm a diabetic. And by the way, the Twizzlers are for my husband.

image.caption: Molly Jean goes for candy with high sugar value.

pageElements.text:
Molly Jean's Picks

I must have gum. For meals, Subway sandwiches and chips. If I have to eat fast food, Wendy's. It always grosses me out about two-thirds of the way through the burger, but I do love the fries. For treats, a bag of really sugary candy, like Sour Patch Kids, Good and Plenty, and Mike and Ikes.

My family's latest indulgence is fresh-popped popcorn (made before we leave the house); a nice, big glass of Coke in a Tervis tumbler full of ice; and plenty of napkins. Heaven! The popcorn travels in a large brown paper grocery bag.

image.caption: Neatness is prized in the Christina Lawson vehicle.

pageElements.text:
Christina Lawson's Picks

I generally don't like to eat in the car (it gets messy), but my one rule is that the food has to be as self-contained as possible. Nothing that requires peeling, nothing that crumbles, nothing that requires mixing, nothing that requires utensils.

Favorites: Grapes, pre-peeled oranges, blueberries, raspberries, hulled strawberries, prepackaged crunchy snacks like Cheez-Its (preferably reduced fat: no greasy residue on your hands) and pretzels, grapes, cherry tomatoes, carrots, celery, string cheese, pre-made peanut butter sandwiches (no jelly), and protein bars.

Least favorites: Anything with a pit, a core, or a peel; anything (like melon) that causes sticky fingers; pastries. I'm on the fence about things like cereal and trail mix. You never know when (not if) something is going to miss your mouth and land on the floor to get stepped on.
I believe in keeping a trash container in the car, as well as napkins, wipes, tissues, and hand sanitizer to clean up before and after eating.

Annie White's Picks

I've always felt strongly that there are times in life when attempts at healthy living must be abandoned in favor of eating and doing whatever you damn well please, because life is short and taste buds die. I apply this philosophy on holidays, birthdays, any day when I've spent more than two consecutive hours exercising, and, of course, during road trips. Healthy food for the car? No, thank you. Salty snacks, please, with a side of ice cream from the gas station.

I have a few go-to snacks that have been elevated to a place of honor in the road food hall of fame. Cheetos, Funyuns (gross, I know), pretzels, beef jerky, salted cashews, peanut butter M&Ms, and sour gummy worms are consistent favorites. Their only value is that I love eating them, and it's possible to do with eyes on the road and a hand on the wheel. I also keep apples and bananas on hand for when I get that horrible feeling that I get when I haven't consumed any valuable calories in days.

image.caption: Annie White knows that the good life involves an occasional burrito (left) or slice (right).

pageElements.text: When I'm lucky enough to be starting a road trip from Ann Arbor, I go to Zingerman's Deli and buy a fantastically expensive BLT to eat at a picnic table at a rest stop somewhere.  Worst road trip food: burritos. Because you will look like this (left) when you try to eat one while driving.

Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

Aloha Wanderwell

Leaving the actresses behind momentarily, we return to an adventurer. Aloha Wanderwell, like our intrepid pioneers Bertha Benz, Alice Ramsey, and Anita King, was known for breaking a barrier: she was the first woman on record to have driven around the world. Unlike them, she was not necessarily a good girl. Aloha Wanderwell was rumored to have played a role in the murder of her husband.

Born Idris Hall in Canada, and later as a student in a French convent school, she dreamed of traveling the world. At the age of sixteen, she got her chance when she was hired as secretary and driver on an around-the-world film expedition. The leader was Walter Wanderwell, a Polish seafarer and traveler who styled himself as Captain even though he held no real military rank. Driving custom-fitted Ford Model Ts, the expedition traveled through forty-three countries between 1922 and 1925, including Morocco, China, Romania, Egypt, and Siberia.

Why the Model T?

Aloha wrote of the expedition's Model Ts that the Ford was "the only vehicle" for a trip in the 1920s. "Light weight: can be raised by its occupants. Good clearance: imperative. Repairs: simple. Basic: the only global spare parts service makes it the most influential auto. The Flivver will open the roads of the world." She seems to have not just endured, but enjoyed the ride. In her writing, she mused that "the confines of a car, its reassuring purr and motion, breeds an extraordinary sense of isolation, intimacy, privacy."

Aloha served as interpreter, seamstress, laundress, mechanic, cinematographer, and film editor on the expedition. In 1925, she also became Wanderwell's second wife. Their collaboration included intrepid episodes such as the time their plane crashed in the Amazon basin, and Aloha had to be left behind for months while Walter made his way back to civilization to get parts to repair the plane. She used the time to make a movie, Flight to the Stone Age Bororos, which is now in the Smithsonian's Human Studies Archive.

They came out of their around-the-world voyage with a film, With Car and Camera around the World, prominently featuring Aloha, and hit the lecture circuit. Some of the nitrate film footage survives, and it's a fascinating look at a more adventurous time in travel.

Murder Mystery

In 1932, Aloha and Walter were in Long Beach, California, preparing for a trip to the South Seas to make another film. On the night of December 5, Walter was shot and killed in the cabin of their boat. Although Aloha was reportedly in Hollywood closing the deal on the documentary at the time, there were persistent rumors that she had a hand in her husband's death.
A crew member from one of Walter's previous voyages, William "Curly" Guy, was tried for the murder but acquitted, and the crime remains unpunished to this day.

Meanwhile, Aloha remarried to another filmmaker, Walter Baker, and together they completed a list of films including Flight to the Stone Age, My Hawaii, To See the World by Car, and Explorers of the Purple Sage. Some are in the permanent collections of the Library of Congress, the Smithsonian, and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

But what happened to the Ford Model T? Aloha donated it to Ford, but unfortunately, Henry Ford himself decided its historical value was limited, and he had it handed over to be used as scrap metal for the war effort  in 1942. Too bad, because it would have been a great addition to the car collection at the Henry Ford Museum.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. pageElements.text: Everyone agrees that texting and driving, or even using a handheld mobile phone to talk while driving, is a bad idea. But a new study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that, like many things that are bad ideas, it continues to be popular. The CDC report asked drivers from the United States and eight European countries about their phone use while driving, and the numbers weren't exactly encouraging.

In fact, it turns out that in 2011, 69 percent of U.S. drivers admitted to talking on the phone while driving at least once in the previous thirty days, and 31 percent say they have texted or even e-mailed while driving. Why is this such a bad idea? Because the U.S. Department of Transportation says that texting while driving makes you twenty-three times more likely to crash, and crashes in which a driver was using a handheld device are four times more likely to result in injury. In response to what CDC director Tom Frieden calls a potentially "fatal distraction," several states have outlawed texting while driving, with some even going so far as to ban all cell-phone use.

We know that, but has it stopped us from driving distracted? Speaking for myself, I completely avoid texting while driving but will occasionally take a phone call from behind the wheel, even though I know I probably shouldn't.

America vs. Europe

The CDC study also told us that U.S. drivers are more likely to engage with their devices than the drivers in the seven European countries included in the survey. Brits were least likely to talk on the phone, with only 21 percent of surveyed drivers copping to talking on the phone while driving in the preceding thirty days. Spain's drivers were least likely to text and drive, with just fifteen percent of those surveyed saying they had done so in the past month. Portugal tied the U.S.'s high for that data point, with 31 percent of drivers admitting to texting at least once.

If we assume those numbers are accurate (I'm inclined to believe that the number of people who talk on the phone while driving is much closer to 100 percent than 70 percent but don't have data to back me up), we still have a long way to go before the road is free of distracted drivers.

Go Cold Turkey

Unfortunately, there's no surefire way to ensure that your fellow drivers will refrain from using their phones while driving. What you can do, however, is try to limit your own temptation to text and drive. If you're unlikely to turn the phone off when you get behind the wheel (or are dealing with a teenager who doesn't take the risks seriously), think about using one of the several smartphone apps on the market that disable texting when it senses that your phone is in a moving car If a text or call absolutely can't wait, pull over to make it. Your fellow drivers will thank you.

pageElements.text: You are looking at Jean Harlow with her 1932 Packard Deluxe Eight sport phaeton on the left and her 1934 Cadillac V-12 town sedan on the right: expensive, conservative choices (especially the phaeton) and both very safe cars for a woman out to protect her career.

So what went so terribly wrong? Ranked one of the greatest movie stars of all time, Harlean Harlow Carpenter from Kansas City, Missouri, was initially a critical failure but had monstrous charisma on the screen as a bombshell with a body that wouldn't quit.
The movie Gallagher was renamed Platinum Blonde to cash in on the name invented for her hair color by Howard Hughes's publicity director, and many of her fans dyed their hair to try and match hers.

Taken to Hollywood by a crazy, overbearing mother who wasn't above offering herself to casting directors who would give her Baby a chance, Harlean eloped at sixteen and was quickly afterward discovered by Fox executives. She signed on under her mother's maiden name, Jean Harlow. After a few bit parts, Jean's big break came on the failure of the Norwegian silent screen star of Hell's Angels, whose thick accent couldn't cut it when Howard Hughes decided to reshoot it as a talkie. Jean Harlow eventually was able to land roles that showed her gift for comedy and became wildly famous at MGM. Her career was brief, however.

British writer David Bret published a book on the actress's eventful life, Tarnished Angel. It detailed how, in the words of one reviewer, Jean was often "drunk, debauched, and drawn to middle-aged men who let her down in bed and beat her black and blue instead of giving her the love she craved."

Lived Fast, Died Young

By the age of twenty-six, Jean had been married three times. Her second husband was found dead at home under suspicious circumstances. It was officially ruled a suicide, although it was rumored that she might have murdered him. She had an affair with the married but separated boxer Max Baer, and, to prevent a scandal from his outraged wife, the studio arranged her third marriage with a cinematographer friend that was quietly dissolved seven months later. She was now a ripe old twenty-three years old. Jean was in a two-year relationship with William Powell after that, but she died suddenly after she collapsed on a movie set and was sent home to rest.

After a week at home under the care of her Christian Scientist mother, without getting better, Jean was rushed to the hospital by William Powell and Louis B. Mayer, and she died there the next day due to kidney failure.

pageElements.text: What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.
Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

Marlene Dietrich

Before we totally leave crazy, uninhibited actresses and their even crazier families behind, let us note the absolute power exuded by two international superstars and their choices of cars, starting with the great Marlene Dietrich.

Absent fine car magazines for reference, the fan of the day frequently judged a car by its owner and vice versa. At the top of her game in this photo, the sultry, gender-bending German goddess Marlene Dietrich lounges with her ungodly 1934 Cadillac 452-D V-16 town cabriolet: a rare beast and a forbiddingly expensive one. But before she had a Cadillac, she had a green 1929 Rolls-Royce Phantom I, given to her on her arrival in Hollywood by Paramount in 1930. If you watch Morocco, her first American film, you'll be sure to see the car. Both the Cadillac and the Rolls-Royce are still in existence today. The Cadillac is housed in the Southward Car Museum in New Zealand, and the Rolls-Royce sold for $524,000 at auction in January 2012 to a private buyer.

Sonja Henie

Sonja Henie was a child athlete in Norway, skating in the first Olympic Winter Games in 1924; winning gold in 1928, 1932, and 1936 for figure skating; and ranking as Norway's third-best tennis player before she came to America to star on the silver screen.

If you think the outrageous and exceedingly avant-garde 1936 Cord 810 shown here was an unusual choice for young Sonja, you'd be interested to know that she also had another Cord back in Norway, an L-29. And that Tyrone Power had a black and white 810 convertible to match hers. And that she had an affair with Joe Louis. (These actresses and their boxers!) And that she sat in Hitler's lap.

I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. pageElements.text:
You probably already know about gas/electric hybrids, plug-in hybrids, and electric vehicles. (If you don't, see our story Green Cars: Deciphering the Choices.)

But what about green cars that are none of the above? The search for what will replace the gasoline engine once we've sucked the oil wells dry is still on, so in the interest of fair time, here's a look at some alternative alternative fuel schemes. Don't get too excited: these technologies aren't quite ready for prime time. But who knows what the future may hold?

Compressed Air

French automaker Peugeot unveiled the Peugeot 2008 Hybrid Air crossover at the Geneva Auto Show earlier this month. It's a hybrid designed for city driving that pairs a gasoline engine with a hydraulic motor powered by compressed nitrogen. The nitrogen is stored in a tank under the car, and when the driver decelerates or brakes, that action causes it to compress. The kinetic energy stored in the compressed nitrogen can then be used to power the car for up to 80 percent of city driving, depending on the traffic. More traffic, and thus more braking, will allow the car to be powered by nitrogen, or basically to run on air, for a greater percentage of a trip. Peugeot says this technology could get the car to as much as 81 mpg in the city, where its regenerative braking capability would be most useful.

Peugeot's Hybrid Air system is experimental for now, but the company hopes to have the technology in European showrooms by 2015 or 2016. Peugeot expects the price of the eventual production car to be in the neighborhood of $26,000.

Natural Gas

Compressed natural gas has several benefits as a fuel source. Cars that run on natural gas release up to 45 percent fewer smog-producing emissions and up to nine percent fewer greenhouse gas emissions than cars that run on gasoline. Natural gas is also cheaper than gasoline, and the vast majority of the natural gas used in the United States is also produced here, so it has that whole reducing dependence on foreign oil thing going for it.

The only production passenger car currently for sale in the United States is the Honda Civic Natural Gas, which returns 27 mpg in the city and 38 mpg on the highway. It has been lauded as one of the greenest cars on the market. There is also the Ram 2500 CNG, a natural gas pickup that is used as a fleet vehicle and recently made its way to showrooms after dealers expressed an interest in the technology. So why isn't everyone driving a car powered by natural gas? Because natural gas pumps aren't nearly as ubiquitous as gasoline or diesel pumps, so while this fuel is cheaper, it is also much harder to come by.

Fuel Cells

Cars that are powered by fuel cells use the reaction between hydrogen gas and oxygen to power an electric motor that drives the car. Water is the only by-product of this reaction, so fuel cell vehicles qualify as zero-emissions vehicles. The catch? Pumps that sell the hydrogen gas that these cars run on are even harder to find than natural gas pumps. The Mercedes-Benz F-Cell, leased to only fifty celebrities and early adopters, is only available in California because only that state has even the beginnings of a hydrogen fuel network.

Mercedes-Benz's F-Cell isn't the only fuel cell vehicle the company has toyed with. At last year's Los Angeles Auto Show, the company unveiled the Mercedes-Benz Ener-G-Force concept, a spin off of the G-Class that runs on hydrogen fuel cells. It imagines what an off-roader could look like in 2025.

While the EPA's fuel economy website dismisses current fuel cells as "far too expensive for most consumers," there may be more affordable fuel cell cars on the horizon. Ford, Daimler, and Nissan announced this year that they will be teaming up to produce an affordable mass-market fuel cell car, with hopes to have vehicles on the road as early as 2017.

What's Your Take?

Do you think these technologies have a future, or should carmakers stick with the green technology they have now? Comment below!

pageElements.text: If you've ever thought about taking cleaning and waxing your car into your own hands but have not known where to start, now could be the time to make the leap. It's officially spring, so the thought of being outside shouldn't leave you shivering, and your car is probably in need of some loving attention. For those of us in the north, that's especially true because our cars have been coated in a fine layer of slush and salt all winter.
I'm going to walk you through the steps to a shiny car.

1. Shop for the Right Tools and Equipment

First, get your hands on some of the great products out there that make it easier. I'll lay them out as we go through the steps. You should always read the instructions for any products you use on your car to make sure you're using the right one for your vehicle and applying them correctly.

2. Start with a Wash

Washing your car regularly is an important part of car maintenance. It can help prevent rusting and will wash off compounds that could otherwise bind themselves to your car's paint and cause damage. If you're washing your car yourself, make sure to use the proper cleaning agent. Household detergents can damage a car's paint and cause premature rusting, so make sure you use a cleaning product designed specifically for cars. Also be sure to use wash mitts, sponges, and towels designed for use on cars. Household sponges and towels could scratch the car's paint.
Of course, if you're not inclined to wash the car yourself, professional car washes all use soap that is safe for cars.

3. Step Up to a Deep Clean

If you're really looking to get in your car's good graces, take the time to do some deep cleaning. There are plenty of products out there for cars in every state of disrepair. If you haven't waxed or polished your car in a while (or ever), you may want to start by using auto detailing clay. This will remove contaminants that are clinging to the surface of the paint. Auto supply stores sell clay bars, lubricant, and microfiber towels for this.

Spray a layer of lubricant on the surface of the car, then gently rub a piece of auto detailing clay over the lubricated area until it glides smoothly.This means the clay has picked up all the grit it can from the car's surface. Next, dry off the area you clayed with a microfiber towel. You should be able to notice that the "clayed" areas feel smoother than the areas you haven't clayed yet.

image.caption: Polishing can be easier with a power tool.

pageElements.text:
4. Polish

The next step in a thorough car detailing is to use paint cleaner to remove imperfections that are lurking under the paint's surface. Paint cleaner requires somewhat forceful application, so if you're not interested in doing all that work by hand but still want the benefit of having used a cleaner, look into buying a dual action polisher. These tools cost more than $100 but they're big labor savers; they have oscillating heads that can work in the polish with minimal input from you. Unlike traditional circular polishers that the professionals use, these tools won't damage your paint if they're not used properly, so they're a good choice for beginners. If your car has a scratch deep enough to penetrate the clear coat, you should take it to a professional to have it fixed.

5. Wax On, Wax Off

Once you've polished, you're ready for waxing and finishing touches. If you're waxing your car by hand, use a foam sponge to apply a thin layer of wax to the car's surface. There's no need to lay down a thick coating; this will only make the wax harder to wipe off without providing any real benefit. If you'd rather not do this by hand, you can use an oscillating tool for wax application, too. Once you've laid down a thin layer of wax, wipe it off and admire your handiwork.

The whole wash-and-wax process might seem like a lot of effort, but it will protect your car from damage much better than a plain old wash, and your car will look so good. Even better: you should only need to polish and wax your car once or twice a year, with minor maintenance between deep cleans.

Dorothy Paget

Dorothy Paget was a filthy, filthy rich British aristocrat who hated men. No, really. She did. Dorothy was and is probably best known for her racehorses, but she also owned racing cars. In 1930, she bought three Bentleys belonging to Tim Birkin, a famous racing driver, and financed his project to construct five supercharged Bentleys for racing. This resulted in a partnership that lasted for three years, and the Blower Bentley, which never won first place in a single race and incurred Walter Owen Bentley's displeasure. (Bentley was against supercharged engines.)

According to Quintin Gilbey, author of Queen of the Turf: The Dorothy Paget Story, Dorothy was known as the "richest unmarried woman in Britain." She also may have been one of the more eccentric ones. Dorothy slept during daylight hours, waking at night to eat breakfast and place exorbitant bets, sometimes on races that had already ended. When she went to the theater, she bought two seats (one for herself and one for her purse). She always wore the same coat and hat when she went to the racetrack, and she lived in fear that her car would fail her after her Rolls-Royce broke down on her way to a race. And doesn't it just make sense that she would be driving a 1929 Mercedes-Benz SSK roadster, the perfect high-powered missile for looking good in Germany on the cusp of the Nazis?

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: If you're one of the unfortunate souls who spend your life cursing pollen in all its forms, or if you spent your childhood avoiding the cheap but adorable nickel earrings sold at mall kiosks, Ford has good news for you. Finally, there is a car designed specifically with the allergy afflicted in mind.

The engineers behind the 2013 Ford Fusion have gone to great lengths to ensure that allergy sufferers will be comfortable behind the wheel. For starters, the team of engineers tested more than 100 materials for allergy problems. They avoided using materials like latex, hexavalent chromium (found in dyes, paints, and plastics), and nickel for the car's most touched surfaces (like the steering wheel and center console), since those materials are prone to cause allergic reactions. Ford also chose to limit the use of dyes and formaldehyde in the car's fabrics to further limit the chances that the car will contain allergens.

Ford is also seeking to reduce in-car allergen levels by testing and installing cabin air filters. These air filters catch dust, spores, pollen, and fungus, as well as soot, smog, and smoke, and prevent them from entering the car.

Sync's Allergy Alert App

Ford vehicles equipped with Sync have already been helping allergy sufferers with the Allergy Alert app, which can give drivers location-specific allergy information and inform them of asthma and flu risks without their eyes leaving the road. This new focus on allergens is just one part of Ford's larger plan to leverage the connectivity offered by Sync to help drivers maintain their wellness on the go.

But the best news of all? Drivers don't have to pay a premium for a non-allergenic car. Every 2013 Fusion and 2013 Escape benefits from the research, and Ford says its other new cars will have to live up to the new allergy standards going forward.
