pageElements.text:
What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.

Here's another in our series on women who have done great things with cars.

Elizabeth Junek

Everyone is born too late for something. I was born too late to see the teeny, tiny Madame Elizabeth Junek race the 1928 Targa Florio and almost beat Nuvolari, Divo, and Chiron, the greatest drivers of the day. But I was not born too late to meet her.

There is no doubt that Madame Junek, as she was commonly known, was the greatest woman driver of her era. Here's my column from the April 1994 issue of Automobile Magazine about the day I spent with Madame Junek late in her life.

Another of the Anciens Pilotes de Grand Prix goes to the great Nurburgring in the sky.

One of French Grand Prix driver Rene Dreyfus's oldest friends, and a racing colleague from pre-World War II Grand Prix and Targa Florio days, has joined him in passing from this life. Czechoslovakian hill-climb master in the 1920s. Winner of the 1927 Grand Prix of Germany in the 3,000-cc class. Contemporary of Dreyfus, Albert Divo, Louis Chiron, Tazio Nuvolari, Luigi Fagioli, and Giuseppe Campari, and their better in the grueling 335-mile Targa Florio, though never its winner. A tiny, little...woman.

Oh, she was beautiful, Eliska Junkova, and she was the darling of the Bugatti factory. Ettore Bugatti was stunned when she showed up without her banker husband Cenek to have some work done on the 1922 Grand Prix car she had modified for hill-climbs, having driven the 378 miles from Prague to Molsheim by herself in a rainstorm. "He asked, 'Where is your mechanic?' I said, 'He's at home. I drove myself!'"

I met Elizabeth Junek (as she was more commonly known in the West) when she was eighty-nine, on my way across central Europe six months after the Berlin Wall fell. Stirling Moss told me about her and insisted I stop and see her in Prague. I didn't have Madame Junek's address, but hers was the kind of fame and adoration that called for a mere name on an envelope and it would find its way to her. She was a national hero. The desk attendant at my hotel knew who she was, found her phone number, and arranged the meeting. I had perfume for her and bought her every flower I could find in Prague. The urbane Latvian and retired Porsche design chief Tony Lapine was with me as cultural attache. Our photographer, Maria Krajcirovic, is a Slovak, although she was living in Michigan at the time.
We cooled our heels as she donned dress, stockings, heels, scarf, and makeup. We pored through her racing scrapbooks, each carefully numbered, every photo captioned.

Madame Junek's doctor was just leaving her apartment in the Swedish embassy building. Madame Junek was a little disoriented but welcomed us in, and we were asked to wait in her drawing room until she could tidy up. She came no higher than my chest and looked so frail. I was worried that she wasn't up to the visit from strangers. Ha. She had us cool our heels for nearly an hour as she carefully donned dress, stockings, high heels, scarf, and full makeup. We pored through her racing scrapbooks, each carefully numbered, every photo captioned. The woman who eventually emerged from the bedroom looked much less ancient and closer to the stylish, laughing young woman in the fur-trimmed coat and racing goggles who starred in the yellowed news clippings we had been fingering. We leapt to our feet, and she addressed each of us: she spoke flawless English to me, German to Lapine, and Czech to Maria. "Do you mind if I stand?" she asked. "My legs..."

And so we all stood. For four hours. I asked her a single question about her racing days, and the story came forth without cease, a nonstop narrative in a lovely accented English. Her train travels across Europe with her sister as a young girl. Her first sighting of a car in the south of France before World War I. The banker who fell in love with her when she was a teller, and whom she eventually married. Their success on the hill-climb and Grand Prix circuits of Europe. The time her husband bought her a dress in Paris as a reward for winning a race. ("A supreme sacrifice for a man, to go to the dressmaker." She laughed.)

Madame Junek told her story rooted to that spot in the kitchen. She never moved the entire afternoon. Lapine wavered but never faltered from his respectful standing position next to her. Maria had collapsed into a chair after maybe the first two hours and a few rolls of film. My concern for Madame Junek's health eventually became concern for my own, but it was clear that this story had a beginning, a middle, and an end. An end she was nowhere near. I couldn't break the spell. She talked on.

Her first Targa Florio in 1927, and how she invented the now common practice of walking a course (Yes! She walked the sixty-seven-mile course with her husband) and mapping it out. (Her first practice run was a mere thirty minutes slower than the fastest lap of the 1926 race.) How Emilio Materassi, the Bugatti factory driver, taunted her diminutive physique, and how she flaunted her superior intelligence in his face. How she crashed out of the race on the second lap. The official reason: faulty steering. ("It was sabotage. They put a rock inside a turn just before I came through.")
Madame Junek started fourth in the Targa Florio in a supercharged 2.3-liter Bugatti Type 35B, two minutes behind the great Albert Divo in the same type of Bugatti.

Mostly, she talked of her return to Sicily in 1928, and her greatest drive. Madame Junek started fourth in the Targa Florio in a supercharged 2.3-liter Bugatti Type 35B, two minutes behind the great Albert Divo in the same type of Bugatti. By the end of the second lap, she was leading the race, a mere thirty seconds behind Divo on the road. At one point, she even passed Divo and held an amazing two-minute lead over him and Chiron, Dreyfus, Nuvolari, Campari, and Materassi behind him. Overheating problems dropped her back, but she was able to hold on to fifth place, less than nine minutes from winner Divo. Madame Junek also turned the second lap's fastest time.

Can you imagine what it was like for us to be transported so completely back in time by this tiny old woman who was not only there, but who was the main event? It was her life, those few years in the 1920s, a life that filled four huge scrapbooks with headlines and smiling photos. A life that filled her little apartment with medals and trophies and photos of our greatest racing heroes. That life ended two months after the 1928 Targa Florio, when Cenek Junek was killed in the Grand Prix of Germany. Eliska Junkova never raced again.

The spell was broken, and Madame Junek asked if we would have a drink with her. She fished around in her little refrigerator and came up with a nearly empty bottle of Johnnie Walker Red. She fished around in a cupboard and came up with three little liqueur glasses and one large snifter. She proceeded to pour. "A little one for you," she sang. "A little one for you. A little one for you. A big one for me." She half-filled the snifter, raised it to us, and smiled. "I have bigger," she said. And we drank.

I talked to her a couple of summers ago, and she sounded so far away, and so old. I saw her close friend Czech automotive journalist Milan Jozif at the Detroit show, and I asked him about her. "Eliska is very ill in the hospital. 'Life is beautiful,' she said to me. She fights to live." Jozif called me the next day. "I'm afraid Eliska is no longer with us. She died yesterday, maybe when we were talking about her. It was seven weeks exactly from her ninety-third birthday."
I will always remember her.

Helle Nice

Helle Nice lived a fast life both in and out of the car. She was born in 1900, daughter of a French postman, under the name Mariette Hélène Delangle. Her first career was as a dancer in the music halls of Paris. Then, in 1929, she entered and won the all-women's Grand Prix at Montlhery, France, driving a French Omega Six racing car. That was only a prelude to several years of competition in mainstream racing against male competitors. She toured U.S. racetracks in a Miller in 1930 and raced a Bugatti Type 35C and an Alfa Romeo 8C Monza in Grands Prix all over Europe in the years before the outbreak of World War II. She set speed records and partied hard with some of Europe's wealthiest personalities.

It all began to change for Helle in 1936. Driving an Alfa Romeo Monza in the Sao Paulo Grand Prix that July, she hit a hay bale, and her car became airborne and killed several spectators. Helle was thrown from the car and landed on a soldier, who died from the impact but broke her fall, saving her life.

After that, despite occasional amnesia, she continued to drive, notably in rallies. In the Chamonix Rally, she was co-driver to Baron Huschke von Hanstein. After World War II, on the eve of the Monte Carlo Rally, Grand Prix racing driver Louis Chiron publicly accused her of being a Gestapo collaborator. This accusation was never proved, but nevertheless she became persona non grata.

She died, alone and shunned, in Nice in 1984, but her colorful story has not been completely forgotten: a biography, Miranda Seymour's Bugatti Queen: In Search of a French Racing Legend, was published in 2004.

pageElements.text: There are many days in the recent past when I have felt like a taxi driver. Picture me racking up miles in the driver's seat of my minivan, trying out the "You talkin' to ME?!?" line on a nonplussed four-year-old. Not pretty.

This is a feeling common to the average overscheduled parent. If you have kids, and especially if you have kids and a full-time job, you probably spend a chunk of time worrying about getting them to Point A to Point B, not to mention Points C, D, and E. You do start channeling your inner taxi driver after you've ended each day racing to get your child from preschool before they start charging the $5-per-minute late fee. You haven't lived until you've faced the regular scenario of having to pick up two kids at two different schools, get one to soccer practice on the opposite side of town, take the other one to a music lesson, and then go back to get the soccer player.

So on the day when I first saw the brightly painted Kids Kruiser minivan around town, I knew a light bulb had come on over somebody's head. I tracked down Angela McCommons, president of Kids Kruiser, and the minute I met her I knew I had found a woman with a better idea about transportation for kids.

A Taxi for Kids!

Kids Kruiser is a two-year-old company in Ypsilanti, Michigan, with the mission of providing safe and reliable transportation for children from preschool through high school. McCommons has a three-vehicle fleet, two Chrysler minivans and a Ford Fusion, and she employs four part-time drivers. Between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m., customers can get their kids picked up and dropped off in a wide swath of the Ann Arbor/Ypsilanti area. The service works similar to a taxi but with many kid-friendly touches. McCommons says that what Kids Kruiser is providing is "a familiar experience, the same as what kids are used to." So the vehicles are squeaky clean inside and equipped with board books, booster seats, and even Nook Readers with kid-friendly items installed on them. The Fusion is decorated in a more teen-friendly way, with racing stripes, but the whole fleet is immediately recognizable. "I didn't want kids to have trouble finding it," McCommons says. No worries there!

McCommons, 35, is an engineer by education and training and worked for Chrysler before starting the business. She already has some 100 families registered with the service. Kids Kruiser also has a relationship with the local Education Project for Homeless Youth, so the brightly colored vehicles pick up and drop off children in temporary housing or shelters who might not have reliable ways to get to school or activities.

On a recent afternoon, I rode in the Kids Kruiser minivan while McCommons picked up a little girl from her preschool. This pickup was a regular arrangement with the school, so she just had to pull in to the parking spot at the appointed time, and a teacher brought the girl out in her wheelchair, installed her car seat in the second row of the minivan, and strapped her in. The wheelchair folded to fit neatly in the back of the van, and we were on our way.

Brilliant App

Here's the best part of the Kids Kruiser setup: McCommons, working with a local app developer, created a custom app to allow her to notify parents immediately by text that a Kids Kruiser driver has picked up or dropped off their child. I watched her pull a card with a QR code (one of those square black things) from a file in the driver's compartment and scan it with her iPhone. This automatically sent a text to the girl's mom that she had been picked up. McCommons issues iPhones with the app to every driver so they can do the same. She comments: "We have lots of parents in the medical profession. They are very busy and can't get phone calls, but they can look at a text and know everything's okay."

images.caption: Angela fits passenger's wheelchair in back of the van.
Once she has dropped off or picked up, she sends a confirming text.
Kids Kruiser brand  is everywhere on the vehicle.
Booster seats are provided.
Kids Kruiser app may be the most innovative aspect.
Teens prefer the racing stripe to the rainbow when they get picked up.

pageElements.text: After about ten minutes on the road, we pulled up at the girl's house, and her mother came out the door with a younger child in tow. The text message had let her know exactly when to expect the Kids Kruiser to arrive. Having safely delivered the girl, McCommons again swiped her card on the iPhone. A confirmation text went to the mom. The app also provides the company the data it needs to keep track of all the vehicles and their activities for the day.

A Premium Service at a Premium Price

Kids Kruiser rides don't come cheap. The company charges $17 for the first five miles traveled, which McCommons says includes a $5 pickup fee, and $2 for each additional mile. If the driver is asked to install a customer's own child seat in the vehicle, it's an additional $5 charge. The kids don't pay on the spot, obviously; parents have accounts and are asked to set up and pay for rides in advance.

This could add up to a not inconsiderable amount of money if you planned to have a Kids Kruiser pick up your child regularly. On the other hand, as McCommons points out, "We're not just a taxi ride. We're in charge of your kid during that time." Besides, have you priced gasoline lately? She makes a point of getting together with each family in person before the first ride ever happens, to meet the child or children and make sure the family is comfortable with the service, and her drivers are very carefully screened.

McCommons is willing to take adult passengers, and she does a little side business in driving college students to and from the airport, but as the decorative vans make clear, her main focus is on kids. This is what you call seeing a need and filling it well.

pageElements.text: If you could add any feature to a minivan, would you even have dreamed of having an actual vacuum cleaner permanently installed in the back?

As a longtime minivan owner, when I think about such a thing, I picture cherubs flying through the sky blowing on horns, elephants carrying banners, and ticker tape parades. But hey, they're ticker tape parades I could easily vacuum up with the help of the 2014 Honda Odyssey's built-in vacuum cleaner.

The HondaVac

Honda has just announced the new HondaVac in-vehicle vacuuming system at the New York auto show, where the 2014 model is making its debut. The HondaVac will be standard on the 2014 Odyssey's top Touring Elite model, which comes out this summer.

This One Has a Shop-Vac Pedigree

Now you may ask yourself (as I did), will this be some wimpy-ass vacuum that doesn't pick up anything? No, apparently not, because it was developed in conjunction with Shop-Vac, makers of industrial-strength vacuums that could just about pull your teeth out of your mouth. That's encouraging for those of us who have lived with unreachable piles of sunflower seed hulls, cookie crumbs, and worst of all, smushed French fries in our vans for years. I believe my current van has crumbs old enough to register for middle school.

Where Is This Wondrous Thing?

The HondaVac comes with a replaceable filter and canister bag, and it is permanently installed in a space on the driver's side of the rear cargo area. Lift the liftgate, select the nozzle accessories that you'll find there, and vacuum as obsessively as you wish. The HondaVac doesn't need to be plugged into an outlet, it never needs to be recharged, and it can operate continuously as long as the Odyssey's engine is running. In fact, you can keep vacuuming for up to eight minutes after shutting off the car, according to Honda.

And Why Am I So Excited It Exists?

I'm guessing everyone who is reading this would agree, it's nice not to have a dirty, crumb-filled car. What stops us from keeping it cleaned out? Mostly the fact that it's such a hassle to go to the plaza outside the car wash and wrestle with the giant hose, which either has no suction, is caked with other people's grime, or eats quarters at an alarming rate. Household vacuum cleaners, when dragged out to the garage or the street, aren't configured well for use in the nooks and crannies of your vehicle. The HondaVac is a no-brainer, seems to me. Can't wait to try it out and see if it works as well as it looks.

pageElements.text: It's been another long, gray winter here in Michigan. Not exactly the kind of weather that inspires people to spend hours outside detailing their cars. But it seems like spring is almost here (knock on wood), so in between weeding your garden and having picnics in the park, take some time to spring clean your car. It may not sound like fun, but performing regular maintenance on your car can extend its life. Here are a few things you can do to help your car recover from winter.

1. Clean the Winter Off

Washing your car regularly is important in helping to avoid rust and paint damage from bonded-on debris. Northerners should be washing your car all winter to minimize the damage from the salt and slush we drive through all season, too. But a deeper cleaning once the weather warms up is a good idea and can help keep your car's paint protected throughout the summer. For detailed tips on how to have your car shining like new, click here.

2. Check (Maybe Change) Tires

If you have snow tires (and we really think you should), make sure to switch back to all-seasons for the warmer months. Winter tires are made with compounds that are specifically designed for cold temperatures. They won't perform their best if you ask them to work in warm weather, nor will their massive treads do you much good on warm, dry roads.
Related story: 5 Rules of Tire Shopping

When you put your all-season tires back on, check the treads to make sure they are wearing evenly and haven't worn down too much. Also make sure all your tires (including the spare) are inflated properly. You can check inside the doorjamb for recommended tire pressure.

3. Give It a Seasonal Once-Over

Jean has already given us some easy tips for seasonal checks for your car, but here's a quick refresher: check the car's fluids (coolant, windshield washer fluid, brake fluid, and oil), and check for damage and wear to rubber connecting hoses, tires, and windshield wipers. It's a good idea to perform this check twice a year, and spring is a good time to start. Coolant, washer fluid, and oil may need to be topped off. If it has been more than 5,000 miles since your last oil change, it might be time to change it. If your brake fluid isn't fairly clear, it could be time to have that changed, too.
This may seem like a lot of work, but it won't be time-consuming, and it will make your car look, feel, and work better. You'll be glad you did it. Happy spring!

pageElements.text: What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.
Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

Josephine Baker

Josephine Baker, like Helle Nice, enlivened the Paris of the era between the two world wars. Both started as music hall performers, but whereas Helle went in the direction of racing, Josephine gained lasting renown as a performer, a dancer, a film star, a French Resistance fighter, and, eventually, a civil rights activist who spoke at the 1963 March on Washington.

Born into poverty in St. Louis, Josephine traveled to Paris in 1925 to appear as a member of a Harlem revue. She met with instant success in Paris, soon becoming a headliner and performing at the Folies Bergere. She became a legendary figure who collected exotic pets, inspired artists, and socialized with the likes of F. Scott Fitzgerald and Pablo Picasso.

Her flashiness was part of her charm. Josephine raced through the streets of Paris in an extremely arty 1934 Delage D8-15 cabriolet. Later, she lived in a chateau in the south of France, married a band leader, adopted twelve children from countries around the world, and ran through her money. Late in life, she was taken up by Princess Grace of Monaco and was in the midst of a comeback when she died suddenly, in 1975. She was the first American woman to be buried in France with full military honors, a tribute to her contribution to the French Resistance and to the love France had for this singular woman.

pageElements.text: It's not every day that you find a compact cargo van worthy of excitement, but Nissan's NV200 mobile guitar repair shop, revealed at this week's New York Auto Show, is that rare cargo van.

The one-of-a-kind vehicle, officially known as the Gibson NV200 Mobile Repair & Restoration Van, is the realization of a partnership with Gibson that Nissan has been interested in for years, according to Nissan product communications manager Phil Lienert. But why the desire to connect with the storied guitar maker? Gibson and Nissan are both based in Tennessee and seek to provide "very desirable consumer goods" that are still accessible (and affordable) to skilled tradespeople.

Everything for the Luthier

The NV200 provided the perfect opportunity for Nissan to realize its dream collaboration. Working closely with the craftsmen at Gibson's Nashville Repair & Restoration shop, Nissan created a special version of the van fitted with a guitar rack, a sliding workbench (complete with tool set), and even a soldering station.

The interior of the Gibson one-off is a significant upgrade, with leather seats instead of the standard cloth: two up front for driver and passenger, and two stools in the cargo area, all emblazoned with the Gibson logo. The Gibson logo is also splashed across the hood and side panels of the van, so there's no mistaking it for something ordinary. The attractive wood veneer inserts in the rear cargo doors and dashboard are also sourced from Gibson.

It's only natural that a vehicle designed for musicians would have a designer stereo system, and this one boasts four retractable Onkyo speakers mounted in the doors and ceilings for deployment at special events.

Even though the Gibson NV200 is a prototype, Nissan has no intention of letting it sit in a warehouse after its turn at the auto show. "This is a working car, and we're going to put it to work," Lienert assured me. Details are still being worked out, but expect to see the repair van at big music and car events in the future.

Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

Violette Morris

Boxing, archery, diving, javelin throwing, weightlifting, soccer playing, Greco-Roman wrestling, racing...Violette Morris was quite a sportswoman. Add to that a bit of heroism, driving a Red Cross ambulance during the Battle of Verdun in World War I.

In 1922, she won the shot put and javelin competitions in the first female Olympic games, held in Monte Carlo. That same year, she entered the Bol d'Or twenty-four-hour endurance race in a 1922 Benjamin Type B cycle car and took fourth place, setting a lap record. She won the Paris-Pyrenees-Paris race in 1922 and was a class winner in the Paris-Nice in 1923.

Violette was famous for her athletic and automotive prowess, but she also drew attention by living openly as a lesbian, for dressing in men's suits, and for fistfighting during soccer matches. The French Women's Athletic Federation refused her request for a license renewal in 1927 and prevented her from participating in the 1928 Olympic summer games in Amsterdam. Violette made the news for electing to undergo a double mastectomy so she would be more comfortable behind the wheel. She ran an auto parts store in Paris until 1929.

In the mid-1930s, Violette was recruited by a member of the Nazi security service and invited to Berlin for the 1936 Olympic Summer Games, where she was received by Adolf Hitler with "much pomp and circumstance," according to Jean-Francois Bouzanquet, the author of Fast Ladies: Female Racing Drivers 1888-1970. After that, it was straight downhill to an evil end for Violette Morris. It's said she provided Germany with information that helped the Nazis take Paris in 1940. She spied for the Germans, transported black market goods, and was said to be an active torturer of resisters. On April 26, 1944, she was killed by members of the French Resistance while out driving in a supercharged Citroen.

pageElements.text: Free is good. We all know that. At the New York Auto Show, Hyundai proved that it knows how to hand out good free stuff when it announced its new Assurance Connected Care program. This is an expansion of the existing Hyundai Assurance program, which grows to include more services this spring when it combines with Hyundai Blue Link telematics.  One of the most important things I learned during my time as a college student was that you should almost always take advantage of free goods or services when they are offered to you (exceptions for unknown substances and food that has already touched the ground). So Hyundai definitely got my attention with this announcement.

Assurance Connected Care will be free for three years in all cars that come equipped with Blue Link, starting on May 16, 2013. That includes most models of the Veloster, Elantra GT, Sonata, Sonata Hybrid, Azera, Genesis Coupe, Genesis, and Santa Fe. Assurance Connected Care includes Hyundai's powertrain and new car warranties and free twenty-four-hour roadside assistance, as well as eight existing Blue Link features: Automatic Collision Notification, SOS Emergency Assistance, Maintenance Alerts, and Vehicle Diagnostics, among others. Check out all the icons in our photo gallery.

The three-year free trial for Assurance Connected Care can also be transferred to subsequent owners of a vehicle.

How the Money Breaks Down

Blue Link's current basic package contains just four of those features and costs $79 per year after a six-month free trial. In order to get all eight of the soon-to-be-free features, current users have to step up to the Blue Link Essentials package, which costs $179 per year after a three-month trial. Once Blue Link officially migrates to the Assurance program, the existing Essentials package will take a hefty price cut. Future buyers will pay just $99 for that package, which includes remote control of door locks, geofencing, speed alerts (especially of interest if you have a household with teen drivers), and voice text messaging capability.

Another Consumer-Friendly Move from Hyundai

Launched during the depths of the recession, Hyundai Assurance started with a buyback program that allowed customers who lost their jobs within one year of purchasing a new Hyundai to return the car and end their loan obligation. Hyundai would cover the difference between the trade-in value of the car and the amount left on the loan, and customers would suffer no ill effects to their credit ratings.

Hyundai is quick to point out that Assurance Connected Care will put it at the top of the heap for provision of free safety services. The GM's OnStar Safe and Sound package, which offers many of the same features as Assurance Connected Care, has six-month, one-year, and two-year free trials for Chevrolet, Cadillac, and Buick drivers, respectively, and then costs $199 per year after that. Toyota offers a year-long free trial of its Safety Connect services that costs $139 after the trial is over, but that trial doesn't match Hyundai's for number of services.
Will Assurance Connected Care make you more likely to buy a Hyundai, or are you unmoved by the promise of a long free trial?

pageElements.text: Anyone who has tried to convince a twelve-year-old child to wear a bike helmet for his or her jaunts about town already knows that bike helmets aren't cool. Sure, they'll save your life, but if the price is a seriously mussed hairdo, are you really going to wear one every time you hop on a bike for a trip around the corner? I think if we're being honest, we've all skipped the helmet once or twice, even though we know we shouldn't.

Anna Haupt and Terese Alstin say they "wouldn't be seen dead" in a plastic-and-foam bike helmet. In 2005, when they both were industrial design students at Lund University in Sweden, they thought there should be an alternative for stylish people who also want to be protected from catastrophic head trauma. So they set about inventing something that seemed impossible: an invisible bike helmet.

The Only Airbag That Can Match Your Outfit

What they came up with almost looks like something out of a sci-fi movie. Dubbed Hovding (the Swedish word for "chieftain"), it's a kind of collar that is worn around the neck like a scarf. It's not exactly invisible (the collar's outer shell will be available in a variety of colors and designs), but close enough. The collar contains an airbag and sensors that detect when the wearer is in a crash, as well as a black box to record data about crashes. When the sensors detect a crash, they trigger a gas inflator that causes the airbag to inflate rapidly to form a cocoon of protection around the wearer's cranium. The whole process takes 0.1 second, meaning that the cyclist's head is protected before it ever hits the ground.

Mohawks Won't Work, But Earbuds Are Fine

Of course, with every innovation there is a downside. Hovding's is that it costs roughly $500 and can only be used once. Once the device has deployed, users will need to buy a new collar, although Hovding gives customers a discount if they send back their spent units and the accompanying crash data, which is used for further research. Punk rockers beware: you can't use Hovding with heavy dreads, a stiff mohawk, or large hoop earrings. Those styles could all impede the airbag's ability to inflate properly, but you can wear Hovding with caps, knit hats, small earrings, and headphones.

Despite the inherent challenges in selling a $500 helmet to people who would just as soon not wear one, Haupt and Alstin are determined to make their product an industry changer. It's not available yet in the United States but has been spreading across Europe, gaining fans, winning design awards, and acing crash tests. Visit their website and check out their video showing the helmet in action, and prepare to be amazed.

Who knows? Maybe five years from now we'll all be wearing airbags around our necks. It may not seem likely, but as Haupt and Alstin say, people who don't think big may call themselves realists, but they're really just "scaredy cats."

pageElements.text: Pat Moss was like the Tasmanian devil. She had a very graphic face, so she could look alternately really striking or formidable, depending on how she was dressed and what she was doing at the time.

Pat was the sister of Stirling Moss, the world's greatest living racing driver. She married Erik Carlsson, one of the most famous rally drivers of the day. She met him while she was rallying, but she didn't begin as a racing driver. In her teens, she was an Olympic-level equestrian. By then, her older brother, Stirling, was winning races all over Europe.

The early photos showed her in equestrian events. Then came a photograph set up by one of the London papers with her driving her brother's rally car, and Stirling riding her horse. It was just a total setup, but she turned out to be brilliant behind the wheel. She quickly turned to rallying, where she became without a doubt the most famous female rally driver until Michele Mouton took over from her in the late 1970s.

Racing History

Pat was a five-time European Ladies' Rally Championship winner. She and co-driver Anne Wisdom contested rallies all over Europe from the mid-1950s to the late '60s. Pat started in a Triumph TR2 that she bought herself and first distinguished herself with a 1958 win in the British RAC Rally in 1958, in a Morris Minor. She drove an Austin Healey 100-Six to fourth place in the Liege-Rome-Liege Rally, which she won outright in 1960. She was also winner of the 1962 Rallye Deutschland. After her marriage to Erik, she switched to the Saab factory team. They competed together in eleven international rallies in the mid-'60s.

Once, while she was dating Erik, she was ahead of him on the road in a rally, racing a Healey, and crashed her car and ended up upside down. The first thing Pat checked was if the side glass windows were broken, because they were very expensive. She was relieved to discover they weren't. So while she was upside down in the car, she was carefully removing the set screws that held the window in place. She was just about to remove the final screw when Eric came around the corner, saw her upside down, jumped out of his car in a panic, and ran to the car and kicked the window in. Much to his surprise, Pat came flying out of the car. What he had on his hands was a screaming, spitting hellcat, yelling, "You bloody idiot! I'm perfectly fine, you've ruined my window."

After they got married, they lived in Monte Carlo for a long time as many drivers did to avoid taxes. When I met them, they lived on the Moss family farm in Tring, northwest of London. Erik mucked out the horse stables and would always admonish Pat to stop swearing and stop smoking because it would set off these horrible coughing fits. She tended a massive flower garden and did the cooking, both activities with an eternal cigarette hanging from her lips. Erik would say, "That's right, pretty mom, light another cigarette." She would respond, "Sod you, Erik."

I spent a lot of time with Pat in the 1980s and early 1990s. By the time I met her, she had already retired from rallying and dedicated her life to driving her daughter and her daughter's horses to horse jumping events all over Europe.

At Home with the Moss-Carlsons

The first time Erik took me home to meet the family, I stayed at Erik and Pat's house. I slept in the den on a fold-out bed with orders to not bloody wake anybody up early in the morning.

Next to me was the bookshelf with all of the family scrapbooks. There was not a single photo in the scrapbooks that wasn't taken by a newspaper or professional photographer. Pat's, Erik's, and Stirling's lives were totally in the public domain. Everything they did was commented on and examined in the newspaper. They were the stars of the day.

Pirelli Classic Marathon with Stirling, Not Pat

I had a chance to drive with Pat in 1989, when Pirelli Tires asked me if I wanted to co-drive with her in a Pirelli Classic Marathon across Europe, from London to Cortina d'Ampezzo. I called her, and she said, "That bloody car didn't kill me back then, and I'm not going to give it another chance." I ended up doing the event with her brother, Stirling, which was the beginning of our nearly thirty-year friendship.

In retirement, Pat wrote two books: The Story So Far, which was a memoir, and The Art and Technique of Driving, which she co-wrote with Erik. Shortly before she died in 2008, she managed to get a speeding ticket while towing a horse trailer.

pageElements.text: Researching and picking out a new car are exhilarating, but the buying process can be daunting. Cars are expensive, and there's a general feeling that the odds of getting a good deal are stacked against the buyer. Huddy Skiba, sales manager at Hyman Bros. Mazda in Newport News, Virginia, says that when customers walk into a car dealership, they are "terrified that they're going to be ripped off. We're just trying to help."

We want to help, too, so we've put together a few pieces of advice to help unravel the mysteries of shopping for your new car. Doing your homework before you ever walk into a dealership can go a long way toward making you feel more confident, so this week we'll be talking about what to consider before you finance a car. Follow along, and we'll break down a different part of the process for you each day.

For today's installment: credit scores. Your credit score is one of the most important factors in determining what kind of interest rate you will be able to negotiate on your car loan. It may not be the most exciting topic, but, like eating spinach, understanding your credit score is a necessary evil.

Credit scores can range from 300 on the low end to 850 on the high end. They are based on your payment history, how much debt you're currently carrying, types of credit you've used and the length of your credit history, and new credit you've just taken on. There are three bureaus that provide credit scores: Equifax, Experian, and TransUnion. You can check your score for free using any of a variety of online credit check services to get an idea of what lenders will see when they pull up your credit history. To ensure you're landing at a legitimate site, go to the FDIC's website for information and links you can trust. If you spot something inaccurate on a credit report, get in touch with the reporting agency and dispute the entry right away.

Only the borrowers with the best credit will get the best rates, so even if a manufacturer is advertising aggressive rates, you will need to expect to pay more if you're carrying a low credit score. So ads offering zero percent financing or other great deals might not be available to you if you don't have an excellent credit history. The closer your score is to the high end of the range, the lower your interest rates are likely to be.

If your credit score is particularly bad, it might be worth trying to raise it before you apply for financing on a car. It will take time, but it could also help you save hundreds or even thousands of dollars on interest over the life of a loan. To move the needle on your credit score, pay down credit card balances, make sure there's nothing wrong on your credit report, and make sure you pay on time. In the meantime, a low credit score does not mean you can't buy a car, just that it will probably cost you more to do it.
Check back in tomorrow for part two, when we'll talk about interest rates and where to shop for loans.

pageElements.text: What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.
Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

Denise McCluggage

Of all the Notorious Women in this series, there is one who is still alive, thank the Lord, and with us. Denise McCluggage is a Renaissance woman, one of the most elegant writers about anything automotive or otherwise, a wit, and a raconteur. And she can still drive the wheels off a car even at the age of eighty-six. I love her.

Denise got a lot of rides and was successful in many races. In the 1950s and 1960s, she raced against some of the greatest names in racing history and more than held her own: Phil Hill, Stirling Moss, Carroll Shelby, Dan Gurney, Juan Manuel Fangio, and many more. She won her class at the 1961 12 Hours of Sebring and the 1964 Monte Carlo Rally and was victorious in several women-only races in the late 1950s, including the Nassau Ladies' Races of 1956 and 1957, each time driving a Porsche 550.
Plus, she was as cute as could be in her polka-dot helmet.

Denise was also an accomplished skier and wrote a well-received book called The Centered Skier plus a memoir called By Brooks Too Broad for Leaping. She also helped found AutoWeek as the Competition Press.

She was married once for a very short time to the actor who played the sergeant on Hill Street Blues, Michael Conrad, with whom she remained lifelong friends. She hung out with Miles Davis when they both lived in New York City and was his close friend. She told me a great story about him. "He had a Maserati for a while. It was broken. I told him, 'Sounds like a timing chain,' and I had no idea if it even had a timing chain! I took him to a friend. The thing that was wrong was the timing chain, so he decided I knew everything.

"[Jazz sax player] Allen Eager took him to Luigi Chinetti's to look at cars." This was a legendary dealership in Manhattan. "It had these cement block walls. Someone honked a horn, and the sound bounced off the walls." Here, Denise broke into a brilliant impression of Miles Davis's recognition of the pitches: "Man, G and E!" So, Denise told me, "He bought a Ferrari because he liked the horn."
Denise was inducted into the Automotive Hall of Fame in 2001 and the Sports Car Club of America Hall of Fame in 2006.

Denise and Me

On one of my very first press trips, with Volkswagen, we were in a high-rise in Washington, D.C., the night before the event. In my room was a list of everyone at the event, and her name was on it. I knew who she was, and I screwed up my courage and called her. I went downstairs and met her for drinks, and we hit it off immediately. She was a real role model for the life I was about to embark on.

Whenever I was fortunate enough to go on a trip to Europe to drive cars and she was on the trip, we paired up in the car. It was really impressive to watch her economy of motion behind the wheel of a car. She was as elegant a driver as she was a writer. One time, I was really ill, and she drove the entire way across Germany and Hungary with me laid flat out on a seat beside her. She drove flat out while I was laid out.

The famous drivers of that era were seriously undercompensated. Today they're sought out for their fame and their stories. She lives modestly in Santa Fe, New Mexico, where she's involved with the Santa Fe Concorso vintage car and airplane event each fall.

Denise is also a brilliant photographer and sells beautiful prints of her portraits of the drivers in the 1950s and 1960s. She holds court at the Tuesday Car Table each week at noon at the Santa Fe Bar and Grill. "You don't have to talk about cars, but you're allowed," she told me. And here's something you might want to make note of: She gives one-on-one driving lessons. Her fee is $1,000 a day. She's mainly teaching guys with hot Porsches, but, she said, "I'm open to everyone." Do it.

You can find her on her website and on Facebook, which she claims not to understand. "My mother's level of technology understanding stopped short of ATM machines," she told me. "My sister's stopped short of the cell phone. You can e-mail me." So go ahead: herself@denisemccluggage.com. Tell her you love her, too.

pageElements.text: Refinement may not be the first word that comes to mind when you think of a Lamborghini. In the Italian supercar maker's defense, that's not exactly what the company is going for.  Lamborghinis themselves are nothing if not aggressive. Just look at the bull that is the corporate logo. The clothes, just like the cars, are intended to be "extreme, uncompromising, and Italian." But for its fiftieth anniversary, the brand seems to have taken its spring collection in a more sophisticated direction.

The items in the collection range in price from a low of $89 for a child's T-shirt to a high of $481 for a women's nylon field jacket. The collection is available online, but if you're itching for a piece of official supercar clothing and can't wait for an order to ship, any Lamborghini dealership or reseller can outfit you for a stylish weekend in your Aventador.

The Spring/Summer Collection

On Lamborghini's website, there's a new catalog featuring pictures of chic models swanning about Monte Carlo in a white Lamborghini Gallardo, dressed in garments from the Lamborghini Automobile Collection's 2013 spring and summer clothing line. These range from T-shirts bearing the name Automobili Lamborghini in bold lettering to more subdued polos and dress shirts for men and women with either discreet raging bulls or shields embroidered on them.

Supercar Materials to Wear

Lest you think the brand name is the clothing line's only connection to the marque, Lamborghini says the clothes and accessories are influenced by design elements in the cars, such as the Aventador's rear light cluster. Some are even made from materials found in the cars, like bracelets made from the same leather used to upholster Lamborghini interiors and bags (none priced below $1,000) that incorporate carbon fiber elements.

Mazda in Newport News, Virginia, says that when customers walk into a car dealership, they are "terrified that they're going to be ripped off. We're just trying to help."

We want to help, too, so we've put together a few pieces of advice to help unravel the mysteries of shopping for your new car. Doing your homework before you ever walk into a dealership can go a long way toward  making you feel more confident, so this week we'll be talking about what to think about before you finance a car. Follow along, and we'll break down a different part of the process for you each day.
Today, we're focusing on interest rates: what to expect, where to finance, and what to think about before you sign away five years' worth of paychecks.

Interest can add thousands of dollars to the total cost of your car (depending on the interest rate and the size and term of the loan), so it's important to get the best rate you can. Average rates fluctuate over time and also vary depending on the lender supplying them. Dealerships, banks, and credit unions will all finance cars. We recommend checking with a few lenders before you commit to one.

By shopping around for rates before you head to the dealership, you can know what a reasonable annual percentage rate (APR) is and negotiate from there. If a dealer can't give you a rate as low as another establishment, don't be afraid to finance your purchase from outside the manufacturer's financing arm.

Warning: the math involved in understanding APR and discounted price offers can get confusing, which is why you should take all the time you need to get a full explanation and make sure you understand it. Skiba warns against assuming that promotional deals (like the popular zero percent APR) are always the best choice. He says that a special interest rate often takes the place of a rebate. He gives a recent example of a 2012 Mazda 3: "We can sell [this car] with $2,259 off sticker price in lieu of special interest," he says, "but if they want the special rate, it adds $1,400" to the price advertised on the dealership's website. Buyers who take the special interest rate will still pay less than the sticker price, but they'll pay about $1,400 more than a buyer who finances at a normal rate instead of the promotional rate. In this case, customers who opt for zero percent financing would also have to choose a thirty-six-month loan, forgoing the chance to take longer to pay off the car.

For Skiba, it all comes down to numbers. "If you do the math, it might make more sense to do the cheaper price" instead of the zero percent deal. Of course, these particulars will vary from dealer to dealer, but make sure you work out the numbers on all the options you're considering before you sign on the dotted line.
Check back tomorrow for part three of our auto financing series. We'll talk about how to decide how much you can afford to spend on your new wheels.

metaDescription: 6 Fun Car Social Media Destinations: Check out our list of six car companies' social media efforts that we deem fun to visit. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: When my sister-in-law, Emily Gilligan, had problems with her 2005 GMC Yukon's transmission, the first place she thought to connect with the auto company was General Motors' social media site. She asked if there were any recalls. "They got back to us within a week and said they were sorry to say that there were no open recalls on our model," she told me. "Of course, I wish they had paid for our repairs," which were just under $2,000, "but I was pleased that they did the research."

Getting in touch with the social media site was easier and quicker for Emily than Googling the problem. She's not alone: it's becoming more natural all the time to look to social media to interact with products and brands we like. The car companies are noticing, and now you can see them on Twitter, YouTube, Instagram, Facebook, and Pinterest. Why would you want to go to a car company's Instagram or Pinterest pages? In part, because the car companies have found ways to make it interesting, enjoyable, and profitable for you to spend time there.

Scott Monty, manager of digital and multimedia communications for Ford, told us that his company's social media goes beyond a straightforward advertisement for its products, looking to engage consumers on a whole different level. Ford uses social media to cover "our major pillars: green technology, fashion and design, parents, and more." As he said, these are all areas where "people aren't necessarily thinking about Ford.

"On average, people look at eighteen or nineteen pieces of research or sites before they make a car purchase," Monty said.  "We work hard to ensure that somewhere along the way they come across Ford content in a social context, because we know that people talk to friends, family members, and colleagues. Word of mouth matters, and our site supports that effort."

It's a clever strategy for the car companies, but beyond that, it means that there's a new, social dimension to your car-buying and car-owning experience now, if you choose to click on it. Here are six social media sites we appreciate, and you might, too:

1. Ford's Social Club

Ford Social began in 2008 as more of a political action site than a social play area. Originally, it was known as The Ford Story. "We developed it to help tell Ford's story when we were testifying in Congress during the financial crisis, as we needed to set ourselves apart from the other domestic automakers," Monty said.

The site has evolved into a combination news site, fan blog, and playground. Its Grab a Badge feature lets you choose icons that show up on your own Facebook page. "Built Ford Tough," anyone? Or how about "I (heart) Hybrids"? It features stories such as "Emerald with Envy," a photo gallery of Fords in various shades of green; readers' own articles about their first cars or their road trips; and a smartphone app called Motor Me that lets you take a picture of your car and make it talk using a message you record. Then you can share this silliness with others. On a more serious note, there's a place to make suggestions to Ford on how to improve its vehicles. There are also various real-life opportunities offered, such as joining Ford at auto shows as a citizen journalist or meeting company executives.

2. Toyota's Philanthropy

Toyota gave away 100 vehicles to nonprofits in both 2011 and 2012 in a program it called 100 Cars for Good. Rather than just issue a press release, it set up a Facebook page, a Twitter feed, and a YouTube channel to make the giveaway interactive. Nonprofit organizations got to apply, and then finalists were voted on via Facebook. You can go to the Facebook link to look at video clips from the winning organizations and look at stats on which Toyota vehicles the groups chose. (Not surprisingly, nearly half picked the versatile Sienna minivan, while nine showed their green credentials by picking the Camry Hybrid or the Prius v.) Plus, your Facebook friends who voted appear in icons on the page. If this page gives you a warmer feeling about Toyota, that's just what the company had in mind.

3. Honda's Owner Love

The band Monsters Calling Home, who recorded videos while riding around in Hondas, are a central part of the Honda Loves You Back Facebook page. Watch their videos, read about them, but also check out the Honda jack-o'-lanterns, the photo gallery of people's Honda logo manicures, and the VTEC logos they've had shaved into the back of their heads. Or, maybe, add your own.

4. Story Time with Volkswagen

Why VW is a storytelling platform that enables Volkswagen owners and enthusiasts to share their VW experiences and check out other people's tales. The company's social media presence has already reached nearly 90,000 followers since its launch last September.

"When we launched the Why VW stories, we partnered with the Poptent creative community to source videos from real-life Volkswagen owners and enthusiasts talking about their cars," explained Leigh Anne Sessions, who works in product and brand communications for Volkswagen of America. For example, "A Rabbit, A Farm, and A Story of Success" is a piece about Bob MacLeod and Steve Byckiewicz who founded a successful business with the use of a diesel-powered Rabbit in the early 1980s. Fast forward to 2013, and that business, Kiss My Face, is a multimillion-dollar natural healthcare company.

5. Fiat's E-zine

Fiat's Facebook page is set up more like a magazine than a mere fan page. There's a professionally filmed storytelling series called Alternate Routes, which makes for enjoyable viewing. Plus, you can upload your own story in the Story Booth, although this is a curated site; you have to wait and get chosen.

6. Under the Blue Arch with Chevrolet

Chevrolet's Under the Blue Arch is based around a fictional Chevrolet showroom. Watch the video, reminiscent of The Office, and select one of the (fictional) employees to watch his or her personal video. Take the quiz to find out which character you are. Download memes featuring the characters! It's all pretty ironic for a salt-of-the-earth brand like Chevrolet, which makes it that much more fun. On a more serious note, you can interact on the Facebook page in a variety of conversations about everything from what an aero grille is to truck talk.

It boils down to this: whether you are talking about friends, food, bars, or cars, social media is all about building and maintaining relationships. "Our primary motivator is to have fun, connect with our fans, and talk about the cars that they have invested a lot of time [and money] in," said VW's Sessions. If you want to connect with your car's parent company, or just see what other people have to say, these sites are good places to do that.

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Blind spots are an unfortunate but unavoidable part of driving a car, right? Checking your blind spots before switching lanes is one of the very first things they teach new drivers. Being aware of your surroundings when you’re driving never gets less important, but it’s also a little annoying to constantly check over your shoulder to see if some jackass is riding in your blind spot.
New car technology has gone a long way towards making the blind spot check less of a guessing game, with blind spot warning systems growing more prevalent in recent years.

20/20 Hindsight

But even if you’re still driving an older model, there's one way to save your neck from the constant twisting and turning necessitated by safe lane changes. Hammacher Schlemmer is here to save the day with its panoramic No Blind Spot Rear View Mirror. The mirror is more than fifteen inches wide and clips over your car’s existing rearview mirror.

Hammacher Schlemmer says the mirror offers a 180-degree view of the road behind you, while traditional rear- and sideview mirrors together only offer 52 degrees of visibility. In plainer terms? No more turning your head to check the blind spot, and more visibility over all. Peace of mind in mirror form.

Don’t worry if Hammacher Schlemmer’s $59.95 price seems a little hefty. Versions of this product can be found all over the Internet and at auto supply stores for a smaller ransom. Check Amazon.com for a wide selection of the extra-long mirrors, then get back to driving and enjoy your panoramic view of the road behind you.

pageElements.text: Researching and picking out a new car is an exhilarating process, but the buying process can be daunting. Cars are expensive, and there’s a general feeling that the odds of getting a good deal are stacked against the buyer. Huddy Skiba, sales manager at Hyman Bros. Mazda in Newport News, Virginia, says that when customers walk into a car dealership, they are "terrified that they’re going to be ripped off. We’re just trying to help."

We want to help, too, so we’ve put together a few pieces of advice to help unravel the mysteries of shopping for your new car. Doing your homework before you ever walk into a dealership can go a long way toward making you feel more confident, so this week we’ll be talking about what to think about before you finance a car. We’ve been breaking down a different part of the process for you each day.

Where Do You Draw the Line?

Today’s topic: how much car is too much car? We’ve got a few tips to help you avoid auctioning off a kidney to afford your monthly payments.

Buying a car can be a budget killer and represents a years-long commitment to set aside several hundred dollars per month for your wheels at the very least. Skiba says customers aren’t always realistic about the cars they can afford. "They want a $25,000 car for $250 a month, and the math just doesn’t work."

There’s a lot of competing wisdom about how much you should spend on a car. If you take Consumer Reports’ advice, you should spend no more than 36 percent of your gross income on debt. This includes a mortgage (or your monthly rent, if you don’t own your home), credit card bills, and any other monthly payments. To determine what you can afford to pay for a car, add up all your monthly expenses and subtract that number from the 36 percent you can spend on debt. What’s left over is what you have to spare for a car payment.

How Much Do You Plan to Spend?

For example: the median household income in the United States is just under $53,000. Using our 36 percent benchmark, that household can spend about $19,000 per year on debt payments, or about $1,600 per month. Just for the sake of round numbers, if you have a $600 housing payment and another $400 in other debt, you’re left with $600 for new debt, like a car payment.

Bankrate.com, a personal finance site, has a different rule of thumb. They suggest that you spend no more than twenty percent of your monthly income on your car, which includes payments for insurance, car maintenance, and other operating costs. This means that a household earning $53,000 (about $4,400 per month pretax) should spend no more than $880 per month on car-related expenses.

What About the Down Payment?

Deciding on the size of your down payment is also important. Skiba says that these days, since many dealers no longer require a down payment as part of a new-car purchase, "nobody’s putting any money down. You don’t have to." Putting little or no money down might make it easier to afford a car, since you won’t have to plop down a large lump sum before you get the keys, but it can also mean that you owe more than the car is worth almost immediately, since the value of a new car depreciates quickly once it leaves the dealer lot. It might be hard to come up with a sizable down payment, but it will lower your monthly payments and allow you to borrow less money to finance your purchase.

Also consider operating costs (gas and maintenance) and how much it will cost to insure a vehicle. You’re going to spend more to insure a sports car than a minivan and more to fill up a large SUV than a compact car. Once you have an idea of how much you can afford to pay each month and settle on an amount for the down payment, you can use an online calculator to determine what the total value of your new car should be. Make sure the whole picture fits into your budget.
Check back tomorrow for our final installment on financing, when we’ll talk about how to decide on the length of your loan.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Read this and enjoy the pictures. But also, go see my video story on the Amelia Island Concours d'Elegance over on Jean's Driveway.

The very words "concours d'elegance" give the feeling of a stuffy lawn party with old cars scattered around, restored and polished to a level of shine they never had when they were new.
I call them dead-car shows.

One of the rare exceptions is northern Florida’s weekend-long Amelia Island Concours D’Elegance at the Ritz-Carlton. It’s anything but stuffy. Instead, Bill Warner, the guy who started it eighteen years ago to raise money for local Jacksonville charities, has infused it with all of the passion and love he has carried his entire lifetime for beautiful old cars; vintage aircraft, motorcycles, and racing cars; and for the men and women who raced them, restored them, and own them. I think he knows every person and every car there.

pageElements.text: This year's actual concours d’elegance wasn't until Sunday, March 10, but there were plenty of reasons to arrive rested and ready by Friday morning. Every hallway in the hotel led to an art show; a silent auction; purveyors of vintage posters, models, books; and lots of other cool car crap. There were cars parked on the lawn preparing for auction, vintage car road tours, and test drives of supercars.
Amelia has become famous for its racing and design seminars, led by panels of the most famous racing personalities in history, and now always sold out.

On Friday, there was a design analysis of the original Corvette Stingray, with Peter Brock, one of the car's original designers, joining General Motors' vice-president of global design, Ed Welburn, at the podium.

In the afternoon, nearly 1,000 people came to the fiftieth-anniversary celebration of the Porsche 911 to hear stories from former designers, executives, and famed racing drivers, including Hurley Haywood and Vic Elford.

The ballroom was packed again on Saturday to hear American legend Dan Gurney, now eighty-one, swap never-before-told stories with old drivers who were part of the three teams who raced the Ford GT40 to the first overall victory for the United States at the 24 Hours of Le Mans race. The crowd barely breathed for two hours listening to Gurney, Bob Bondurant, Targa Florio winner Brian Redman, and Formula 1 commentator and rascal David Hobbs. pageElements.text: The day was capped off by a black-tie soiree starring this year’s honoree, the great writer, racer, architect, and on-air racing commentator, Sam Posey. All bow down.

I'm a judge. Don’t be impressed. There were 100 judges this year that broke into groups of two or three for each of the thirty-five classes on the field. If you come to Amelia for autographs, a great place to stand is outside the door of the judges’ breakfast meeting. For the past few years, I have been judging a goofy car class called What Were They Thinking. I call it the Weinermobile class, because one year, I judged a group of cars that included one that looked like a can of V8 with a seat made of leather vegetables, made by George Barris, probably most famous for the Batmobile.

This year, I fell in love with the winner chosen unanimously by our team which included me, Hurley Haywood (who couldn’t go ten feet without being photographed or asked for an autograph) and Keith Martin, the owner of Sports Car Market, read by all buyers and sellers of vintage cars. Gleaming like a little jewel was the tiny little 1959 Messerschmitt roadster, lovingly restored by the very sweet J.C. O’Steen, who threw his arms around me and cried when I put the big fat blue rosette on his windshield.

A filthy, crazy-looking, unrestored heap came in second and as excited as its owner, Dale Walksler, was, he was MORE excited to whisper to me that a plane was about to fly overhead at 2:22 p.m., trailing a request asking his girlfriend, Trish, to marry him.
I spent a lot of time in the judges' viewing stand enjoying the day and still put 20,000 steps on my pedometer, trying to take it all in.
There’s never enough time.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Researching and picking out a new car are exhilarating, but the buying process can be daunting. Cars are expensive, and there’s a general feeling that the odds of getting a good deal are stacked against the buyer. Huddy Skiba, sales manager at Hyman Bros. Mazda in Newport News, Virginia, says that when customers walk into a car dealership, they are "terrified that they’re going to be ripped off. We’re just trying to help."

We want to help, too, so we’ve put together a few pieces of advice to help unravel the mysteries of shopping for your new car. Doing your homework before you ever walk into a dealership can go a long way toward making you feel more confident, so this week we’ll be talking about what to think about before you finance a car.

For our final installment, we’ll talk about the intricacies of loan length.

The Big Tradeoff: Payment Size vs. Interest

Most car loans are between thirty-six and sixty months long. Naturally, shorter loans will have higher monthly payments but they'll also accrue less interest, so you’ll pay less overall by the time the loan is paid off. On the other hand, longer loans and lower monthly payments may be crucial to fitting a car into your budget. Even a seventy-two-month loan has become relatively common in these days of high car prices.

What should really determine loan length is how long you plan to keep your car. Signing a five-year loan with low monthly payments may seem like a good idea, but if you’re planning on dumping your car for a newer model after two years, you’ll still have a large balance when you start shopping for a car again.

Don't Let Yourself Go Upside Down

The key is to avoid owing more money than the car is worth. This is more likely to happen if you have a long loan and a high interest rate and make a small down payment because your vehicle’s value may depreciate faster than you can pay off the principal on your loan. This could cause problems if your insurance provider won’t cover the car for as much as you owe, or if you are looking to trade your car in and can’t negotiate a value that allows you to pay off your existing loan.

The Moment of Truth: Heading into the Dealership

We’ve said this before, but it bears repeating: if you did all your homework, made all your decisions, and you still can’t come to a reasonable agreement with your dealer, walk out. Buying a car is a big investment and not one that you should be pressured into. Take all the time you need to get a deal you feel comfortable with, and if you don’t think you can reach a deal with the salesperson you’re working with, ask for a different salesperson or find yourself a new dealer. There’s no reason to be nervous, though. Skiba believes that buyers who have done their homework and walk into the dealership armed with plenty of information have every reason to expect a good deal.

There’s a lot more to say about the process of buying a car. We hope that this series has helped demystify the lead-up to walking in to the dealership. We’ll be back soon with more tips on the rest of the buying process.

pageElements.text: 2014 Cadillac CTS Sedan

Vital Stats

Base price: Expected to be about $48,000
EPA fuel economy: 17 mpg city/25 mpg highway with top 3.6-liter twin-turbo V-6 and eight-speed automatic transmission
Safety features: Forward collision alert, automatic collision preparation, lane departure warning, side blind-zone alert, rear cross-traffic alert, rear-vision camera, Cadillac's Safety Alert Seat (it vibrates to tell you you're about to crash), automatic seatbelt tightening, adaptive cruise control
Tech features: Magnetic ride control, active grille shutters for better aerodynamics (not on all models), ZF transmission with paddle shifters, Brembo brakes, optional 12.3-inch high-resolution LCD instrument cluster with a choice of four layouts, automatic park assist, twenty-way (count 'em) adjustable front seats
Chief competitors: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Infiniti M, Mercedes-Benz E350

Key Points

—This is the third-generation model of the CTS, based on the same rear-wheel-drive platform as the ATS
—Cadillac is going full bore against Mercedes and BMW with this sedan, and the luxury and tech features show it
—They cut way back on the bling, going for a more understated elegance in this new model
—Cadillac's Art & Science design philosophy goes longer and lower: new CTS is five inches longer, while the roofline is an inch lower
—Aluminum is a byword on this new Cadillac: in the doors, in the suspension, helping cut weight
—There will be eight choices of interior "environments" featuring wood, carbon fiber, and aluminum, plus optional full leather with handcrafted elements in it
—The new Cadillac comes with either a 2.0-liter turbo four-cylinder or a regular or twin-turbo 3.6-liter V-6. With the top twin-turbo V-6 engine, horsepower reaches 420
—Gadget alert! Motorized cupholder lid, adaptive remote start that also turns on your heat or A/C, an electronically locking glovebox, and a set of twenty-way adjustable heated and ventilated front seats

pageElements.text: When you hear the words “muscle car,” you might think about some guy in a black T-shirt with a pack of Luckys rolled up in the sleeve. Wrong! In mid-June, the muscle cars will be muscled through their paces at Summit Motorsports Park in Norwalk, Ohio, as part of a women-only racing event. It’s bundled into a larger all-Ford racing weekend at the northern Ohio track.

During the weekend of June 14-16, women from around the country will be racing their True Street, or completely street-legal, Mustangs and other Fords in the event. Co-sponsored by our sister publication Muscle Mustangs and Fast Fords and the Royal Purple racing oil company, the event is expected to grant notoriety as well as cash prizes to the women who come out on top. The Saturday event grants the winner a six-foot trophy and $250, with $100 prizes to runners-up. The eight fastest get to drag race on Sunday, with the winner named All-Female Shootout champion.

The day will surely come when there are enough women racing in mainstream events that it’s no longer news. Until that time, it will be fun to hear about and watch events like this one. If you want to be there, check the event schedule. If you just want to keep reading about the growth of women's participation in racing, you might want to check out the Royal Purple Ladies Facebook page. How inspiring for the more timid among us to have some female heroes to cheer.
