metaDescription: City Driver: Brooklyn by Lexus. Read our writer's description of a week spent driving a Lexus LS460 over terrain she usually walks in the city. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: I live in New York City, where subways and walking are the preferred form of mobility and how I like to get around the most. On an average, I walk at least one to three miles a day. But I’m into cars in a big way, too; we have three in my family, stored in various garages and on streets around the city. I am also the proud renter of spot in a garage two blocks from my house that’s adjacent to my favorite neighborhood Italian restaurant.

But, for one week of my life, the 2013 Lexus LS460 made me downright lazy. I test drive cars as part of my job as a freelance writer, hence the Lexus, but I also try to be mindful of my own carbon footprint. I believe driving should be treated like a necessity or a purposeful form of enjoyment, reserved for traveling long distances, moving big things, or enjoying as a special treat. I gave up my Michigan lifestyle, which required wheels for every move; one of the reasons I like living in Brooklyn is that everything I need is within a two-mile radius. A car is a nice option here, but not having one isn’t a deal breaker.

However, I am also a hypocrite. When presented with the weighty smart key fob that serves as the entryway to the top-of-the-line Lexus sedan, my walking feet vanished. A quick trip to the preschool: distance 1.2 miles. Must drive. A meeting in the meatpacking district: distance 2.3 miles. Must drive. A trip to the local food market: distance 0.4 mile. Why not drive the Lexus? I also drove it up and down Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive as much as possible, eating up fuel at a moderate rate of eighteen miles per gallon, forgoing the subway train to get to Central Park. Even my young son, a train buff, preferred riding in the Lexus, declaring the sparkly brown paint color known as Fire Agate Pearl his favorite color of the week.

I didn’t feel as if I had to tiptoe in an ostentatious beast just to enjoy the perks. That's what I liked most about the LS. I trod with lean, mean assertion, drawing from the ballsy power of the 4.6-liter V-8 engine, but the easy breezy action of this car seemed to come with its own built-in butler. There was the one-touch moonroof, the one-touch trunk, the intuitive park assist, the heated steering wheel, and the auto door closer. All that was missing was my personal masseuse. I could have pulled over, sprawled out comfortably, and used the Lexus Enform app to order my drive-through spa services, had I indulged in one more week of the languid life. The LS has an interior that is akin to slipping into a big, fluffy bed of Sferra 1,020-thread count Egyptian cotton sheets, all sumptuous leather and wood trim. My car came with the optional semi-aniline-trimmed interior and Alcantara headliner. Cue the ambient beats on the nineteen Mark Levinson speakers! I never wanted to leave.

Reality hit hard when an unforeseen pothole on FDR Drive strained the nineteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels and served as a reminder to stop loafing around and put my feet back on the New York City ground.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. pageElements.text: Are you an Android developer? Could you use an extra fifty grand? If so, Ford has just the contest for you. If not, you still have something to look forward to, because the contest is to create an app that could greatly improve how we track and set goals for our personal fuel efficiency.
Ford announced its Personalized Fuel Efficiency App Challenge at the New York International Auto Show earlier this month.

The automaker won’t release full details on the contest until the official launch on April 24, but it has said that the app should allow drivers to access their personal fuel economy data, share that data (presumably to Facebook or other social networks), and receive tips on how to optimize their fuel economy.

Why It's So Hard to Keep Track of Fuel Economy

Ford is stressing the "personalized" nature of fuel economy numbers, noting that results can differ widely depending on driving style, outdoor temperature, and traffic conditions. In practice, this can mean that focusing on personal fuel economy can make more sense than assuming you’ll always earn the mileage advertised on the window sticker.

Ford's interest in fuel economy monitoring is timely; the Ford C-Max came under fire late last year when Consumer Reports said the C-Max did not live up to its 47/47/47 mpg promise in real-world driving. The publication called out several other automakers as well for the same shortfall between claims and actual road results. Ford maintains that it is possible for customers to achieve the advertised numbers, which is likely where the fuel economy optimization tips come in—reminding drivers to be light on the throttle and use cruise control, for instance. Ford’s hybrid and electric vehicles already have fuel economy coaching built in, but if my own fuel economy is any indication, the drivers of gas-burning cars could use the help, too.

Ford's Development Setup

Developers will be able to work on Ford’s OpenXC research platform. That platform, along with the plug-in module created by OpenXC collaborator Bug Labs, allows third-party developers to create programs ranging from personalized radio stations to navigation applications.

Interested developers will have three months to submit their apps after the contest opens late this month. Then, from August 8-22, the public will have an opportunity to vote on the best apps before the winners are announced on August 28. Check out the details on the contest’s website.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: April isn’t just the first month of reliably springlike weather here in Michigan: it’s also National Distracted Driving Awareness Month. To help us all get in an awareness-raising kind of mood, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has just released data that estimates that at any given daylight moment, there are 660,000 distracted drivers on the roads in the United States, which, you’ve got to admit, is a little alarming.

In a separate report, also released this month, NHTSA surveyed 6,000 licensed drivers on their distracted driving practices. That survey showed that while Americans are concerned about distracted driving—74 percent of respondents favored a ban on handheld cell phone use while driving, and a whopping 94 percent supported a texting ban—we’re not quite practicing what we preach.

How Much Will You Admit?

NHTSA says that about 49 percent of drivers would admit to taking an incoming call while driving, though only about 24 percent said they would place a call from behind the wheel. Only fourteen percent admitted to sending text messages while driving, which seems to indicate that drivers are at least aware of the dangers of texting while driving, even if they sometimes do it anyway.

In Michigan, teens with learner's permits are now banned from using cell phones at all while behind the wheel. (See related story.) That's just one example of anti-distraction legislation around the country. But don’t assume that teenagers are the only ones succumbing to the pull of the smartphone when they should be focused on the road. NHTSA’s survey identified affluent drivers with college degrees as some of the most prone to distraction. Least prone to distraction? Those over sixty-five. Only five percent of drivers in that age group were classified as distraction prone.

Hands-Free Is Not the Panacea, Either

We can all relate to people who drive distracted. Cell phones have made us constantly available, and driving doesn’t always feel like a good excuse to ignore a call from your boss or a text from your kid. I don’t text while driving—a decision made easier by driving a manual—but I do sometimes talk on the phone while driving. I use a hands-free device, but the Department of Transportation says that is not “substantially safer” than holding the phone up to my ear.

And I'm not alone. I’m often in the car with friends who text while driving, but even though they admit that they shouldn’t, they usually finish the text anyway. In fact, the only people I know who never glance at or fiddle with their phones while driving are the ones who don’t drive. That’s all the more reason to observe National Distracted Driving Awareness Month. Let’s all take this opportunity to remember how important it is to turn a blind eye—and ear—to our phones while we’re driving, and maybe by next month, our phones won’t seem as tempting.

title: Michigan Teens, Hang Up and Drive!
promoTitle: Michigan Teens, Hang Up and Drive!
promoTeaserSmall: New Michigan law forbids teen permit holders from using cell phones when they're behind the wheel.
promoTeaser: New Michigan law forbids teen permit holders from using cell phones when they're behind the wheel.
metaTitle: Michigan Teens, Hang Up and Drive!  - JeanKnowsCars
metaDescription: Michigan Teens, Hang Up and Drive! Read about a new law that bans teen drivers from using cell phones behind the wheel. It's in Michigan, and it's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Lately, when I am driving down the road and tempted to pull out my phone, I think about Bonnie Raffaele.

I never met the woman, but she lives in Michigan, like me, and she had seventeen-year-old twins, as I currently do. One of those twins, her daughter, Kelsey, was talking on the phone while driving in January 2010. Unfortunately, the roads were icy and she was an inexperienced driver. Her last words to the person on the other end of the line were, "I'm going to crash." Even though she was only going about 35 mph, she died instantly.
I think about Bonnie Raffaele because what happened to her daughter happens all too often out on the roads, and it completely sucks.

Tiger Mom

Bonnie didn't just curl into a fetal position and never move again, which is probably what I'd do and would be understandable. Instead, she started an initiative that culminated in the passing of Kelsey's Law in the state of Michigan. As of the end of March, teen drivers in my state can't use electronic devices, including phones, while behind the wheel if they are in the permit phase of their driver's licenses.

Here's a photo of Bonnie and family with Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan, celebrating the signing into law of SB 756, Kelsey's Law. Bonnie got everybody from AAA Michigan to the Brain Injury Association of Michigan behind her, along with student, police, and safety groups and a comprehensive list of state representatives from both sides of the aisle.  And rightly so. Because really, how can we say we are helping teenagers be safe drivers if we turn a blind eye to texting and phoning habits while they drive?

This Happens Way Too Much

In Michigan, more than 8,000 accidents have been blamed on cell phone use in the past ten years. Bonnie Raffaele so clearly doesn't want this to happen to any other family that she goes and talks to school groups and shows them her child’s example. Photos of the bright-eyed, happy-looking schoolgirl contrast with the charred wreck of Kelsey’s Pontiac Sunfire, which was T-boned by a Dodge Durango while she was talking on the phone and not giving her full attention to driving.

Who knows how many more teenagers are going to crash because of cell phones? At least in the state of Michigan now, those with Level 1 or Level 2 licenses will have to go without the texts and phone calls while they're driving. A Level 1 holder has taken the comprehensive first part of the required driver education course but needs to complete at least thirty of the fifty required hours of supervised driving before going on to Level 2. At Level 2, a student has taken the second part of the driver education course and is putting in the remainder of his or her fifty hours of supervised driving before qualifying to take the driving test and get a "real" license.

It seems like a complete no-brainer that phones and electronic devices should be specifically excluded during those hours of learning out on the road. Let's hope this will solidify into a habit for the teens who are now subject to this law.

Taking That Pledge

If you're nodding in agreement about rules for teenagers, how about a quick look in the mirror? I have been silencing and stashing my cell phone while I drive for about a week now. It has helped me rediscover the feeling of looking far down the highway and focusing on the traffic, the road signs, and the experience of driving. I can feel how much better I'm driving with no possibility of electronic distraction. Hey, people in the lanes around me: You’re welcome!
Besides, I have seventeen-year-old twins in the car, and I want to honor Bonnie Raffaele—who says, "I cry every day and I probably will for the rest of my life"—by setting a good example.
How about you? Do you have the strength to put the phone down and drive, like you used to do back in the day before there were cell phones?

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Everyone loves to go to the New York International Auto Show, the last big international show of the season, because it's in New York City. I'm not immune.

It always opens right around Easter break, so it's a very popular place to take the kids, in a town where cars are typically yellow and it costs money to ride in them. The New York show is also the place where kids know they're going to find supercars. Rolls-Royce, Bentley, Porsche, McLaren, Mercedes-Benz, Lamborghini, Ferrari—all the dreamy cars are there.

Traditionally, the New York International Auto Show has been the showcase for the European carmakers. They not only like to launch world previews in New York City, but they also bring cars that were just revealed in Geneva in early March that have yet to be seen in the U.S. One example was the Rolls-Royce Wraith, which was an absolute stunner, as you see here.

The star of the show came from Detroit, surprisingly. General Motors split its big model news by revealing the 2014 Corvette Stingray in Detroit and holding the spectacular 2014 Cadillac CTS for a New York debut. Sadly the entire GM exhibit was tucked away in a remote hall, away from the razzmatazz of the rest of the show. They ought to rethink their strategy of having an exclusive place to show their cars and move back where all the action is.

The second really big piece of news, amusingly enough, was the central vacuum in the 2014 Honda Odyssey minivan. The van itself got a mild refresh, but the on-board vacuum made it to national television. Why didn’t somebody think of this ten years ago? you ask. They did: the American Honda Motor Company people all thought it was a good idea, but the Japanese rejected the idea out of hand every time it was brought up. American Honda finally figured out that culturally, women do the cleaning in Japan, and here in the U.S., men typically clean the cars. In any case, its time has come, and Honda made a deal with Shop-Vac for its vacuum.

New York is a cozy show that can be visited easily in a day. Despite the fact that there are typically very few big launches, there’s a disproportionate number of European executives who show up with their entire families and continue on to vacations.

I like to go to New York because I live on a farm, and getting to New York to look at the cars means I can take in a Broadway show. We've done that frequently. Every one I have seen has been right in the middle of the New York Auto Show. I didn't get to any Broadway shows this year, but I did go hat shopping.

This was my big chance to meet up with two famous milliners whom I had been dying to meet for the past year: Jasmin Zorlu, who brought her rolling hat show to my hotel room, and Barbara Feinman, shown at right, who has been making hats in the back of her little hat store at 66 East Seventh Street since 1998. Luckily, my husband and I drove with JKC videographer Scott Allen in Automobile Magazine’s Range Rover Evoque, a Four Seasons long-term test car, so I had room for "a few" purchases.

pageElements.text: People think it’s amazing that we drive from Michigan to the show, but we do it every year. I love the road trip, and it’s a rare opportunity to hang out with my husband and not be in a big hurry. And if we hadn’t driven, well, I wouldn’t own six new hats.
And, yes, we got it all on video. Stay tuned to Jean’s Driveway for the road trip, coming soon.

pageElements.text: I wanted Gerry McGovern to do a design walkaround of the new Range Rover Sport because he is a very accomplished designer. I love listening to designers who know exactly what they're doing and can describe it in exacting detail in their own language.

On one hand, it's hilarious to listen to him with his very British demeanor and choice of words. On the other, here is someone who is extremely competent, with a design vision that is precisely articulated both by him and by the car itself.

2014 Range Rover Sport Autobiography

Safety features: Adaptive dynamics, lane departure warning, traffic sign recognition, automatic high-beam assist
Tech features: Fuel-saving intelligent stop/start; air suspension that automatically varies between two heights; Terrain Response 2, which chooses the correct terrain program for you, including (on this car) Dynamic mode; color head-up display; comprehensive connectivity package with stolen vehicle tracking; installed Wi-Fi hotspot is an option
Looks: Sportier Sports Command driving position, with smaller steering wheel, vertical gear shifter, higher center console; Third-row “occasional” seating is available; wheels available in nineteen-inch through twenty-two-inch sizes
Chief competitors: BMW X5, Mercedes-Benz ML-Class, Porsche Cayenne

Key Points:

—Land Rover introduced this new model at the New York Auto Show because New York City is the city, and the U.S. the country, where the most Range Rover Sport models are sold
—However, Daniel Craig emphasized the strong Bond between Land Rover and the U.K. by driving the Range Rover Sport through Manhattan’s streets as part of the unveiling
—There are four engine choices: two supercharged gasoline engines and two diesels; the Autobiography gets the 508-hp V-8 gas engine; all are paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission
—A diesel hybrid is coming; you can order it in late 2013 for a 2014 delivery
—Weight is down 800 pounds, thanks to lightweight aluminum suspension
—Land Rover wants you to know that 75 percent of the parts on the Sport are unique to it, so it shares the big Range Rover’s name but has its own look and feel
—The all-new Range Rover Sport comes in SE, HSE, and Supercharged models in addition to the top-of-the-line Autobiography you see here
—Red brake calipers and badging help differentiate the Autobiography, as does a set of perforated leather seats available in more than eleven color choices —Even sportier Dynamic versions of the HSE and Autobiography are coming later, Land Rover says
—Perhaps the best conversation starter on the Range Rover Sport is its Wade Sensing feature: It gives you depth information when driving in water up to 33 inches deep
—But you, and most Range Rover Sport owners, will be mainly driving it around town, won’t you?

metaTitle: The BMW Electronauts - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The BMW Electronauts: Read about a website where 700 field trial users of the BMW ActiveE are tracking the numbers behind their EV use. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: BMW’s much-anticipated i3 electric car isn’t on sale yet, but that hasn’t stopped the company from touting the benefits of electric driving. As part of the ActiveE Field Trial, BMW has had 700 all-electric test cars in the field since January 2012, in the hands of early-adopting testers whom BMW has dubbed Electronauts. With more than a year’s worth of testing under their belts, the Electronauts are going public with their driving data.

BMW has just launched the Electronaut Effect website, which provides real data about range, miles driven, charge times, and money and gasoline saved by the 700 drivers of BMW’s ActiveE cars. The data are updated weekly, so you can check in often to see how the numbers change over time.

BMW has found some creative ways to interpret the data it has collected. For instance, the Electronauts have driven just over 6.2 million miles so far. This translates to $754,590 not spent on gas—money that could now be spent on 252,370 slices of pizza or 145 diamond rings.

Shopping for an EV? Check Out These Numbers

The people who might find this most interesting are those who are considering buying an electric car. Are you in that category? Compare yourself to the Electronauts. They drive an average of thirty-six miles per day and spend an average of 4.69 hours per day charging. There is some reassurance for the range-anxious person, too. BMW says that ActiveE vehicles should be able to travel 100 miles on a full charge; the greatest distance driven in a single day has been 367.7 miles.

As far as saving the planet, BMW’s electric fleet has saved 282,000 gallons of gasoline from being burned for travel, which translates to a carbon dioxide reduction of 1,132 metric tons, or the amount of carbon dioxide emissions generated by 166,000 hours of barbecuing. This may be a small pilot group, but there's no doubt the numbers it has generated are interesting and encouraging.

A group of 700 U.S. drivers was recruited to try it out: the Electronauts.

title: Road Atlas Joins the 21st Century
promoTeaserSmall: Rand McNally atlases you won't shrug at: on iPad and e-book, to supplement (or replace) a nav system.
promoTeaser: Rand McNally atlases you won't shrug at: on iPad and e-book, to supplement (or replace) a nav system.
metaTitle: Road Atlas Joins the 21st Century - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Road Atlas Joins the 21st Century. Read about the 90th-anniversary Rand McNally atlas, now available as an iPad app and an e-book. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Rand McNally has just come out with its 2014 Road Atlas, and that is the best sign of spring I can think of. That's because many of my best road-trip memories involve maps. I love unfolding them or leafing through the atlas, plotting a route with a highlighter in my hand, and imagining various routes that I can change as I go. Often I have been the navigator, proud of my ability to get us there and then fold the maps up neatly when we're done.

The advent of electronic aids such as Google Maps and navigation systems should have dealt a death blow to the paper map, but it hasn't. Like vinyl records, which are the music connoisseur's choice these days, the old-school atlas and map have their adherents.
Or, as Jean puts it, "nav schmav." She's a fan of paper maps, too.

Ninety Years of Navigation

With that in mind, come along with me on a little trip back to 1924. Two million Model Ts were produced in 1924 on the Ford assembly line you see at right, and people were filling them with twenty-one-cent-a-gallon gasoline and looking to head off somewhere. Rand McNally met that need when it came out with the very first U.S. road atlas. It was charmingly known as the Rand McNally Auto Chum, and it had no Interstate highways on it; there weren't any yet (not until the 1950s).

The coolest thing about the Auto Chum (besides the name, of course) is that it was organized geographically from east to west, starting with Maine. There's a  poetic implication there, the idea that you would open the book at Maine and drive through the pages until you hit California. It must have made for a bit of a geography lesson for kids on road trips, too.

From that auspicious beginning, Rand McNally atlases have lived on the back seats and in the map pockets of cars for ninety years. Lately, there are lots of electronic solutions to the question of "Where are we?" So, is it time to give up on the printed atlas?
Don't bet on it. For a ninety-year-old, Rand McNally is spry, and so the venerable company has come out with its 2014 edition in three formats: paper, iPad, and e-book.

Three Ways to Atlas

The e-book ($4.95, for iPad, iPhone, and iPod Touch) has features you also find in the printed version, such as a city locator, a mileage calculator, and tourism contact numbers and links. Once downloaded, it's also usable at times when you don't have Internet access.

I tried out the iPad app ($4.99) and found that it is pretty much a duplicate of the atlas. There are no pop-ups, no links, no newfangled games to play: you touch the name of the state, and you get the same map that's in the printed atlas. You can enlarge it, which is an improvement. It's better than Google Maps in that you can use it offline, but not as good in that you can't ask it to give you directions. I think it's something I will be glad to have on my next road trip as an easy-to-use, familiar friend alongside the Google Maps directions I will have printed out. The iPad atlas will surely entice me to toss the directions aside and explore some side road I hadn't considered, and that's what road trips are all about.

title: Our Rules of the Road
subTitle: Our editors live by three rules when planning a trip. (We don't all agree on what the rules are.)
promoTeaserSmall: What's your packing style?
promoTeaser: Our editors live by three rules when planning a trip. (We don't all agree on what the rules are.)
metaTitle: Our Rules of the Road - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Our Rules of the Road: Read the JeanKnowsCars.com editors' rules for preparing to take a road trip. Each of us has her own list and her own style for traveling in the car. See them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: We like to do things in groups of three, as you know if you watch Jean’s You Auto Know videos. It’s a good way to break any task down into manageable parts. For that reason, I asked our editors to come up with their top three rules when they’re setting off on a road trip. And here they are, starting with my own. You'll notice that we have very different styles of packing for a trip. Which JKC editor are you?

Laura Sky Brown: Same Hippie, Different Decade

I have gone on many extended road trips. The first one, at age eighteen, when I didn’t even have my driver’s license yet, was an extended five-week journey all over the country. Stuffed into a Chevrolet Vega with a teenage friend and her large dog—so, with barely enough room to sit, let alone bring stuff—we traveled from Michigan to Washington State, then from Washington to western Massachusetts, by way of the Grand Canyon and nearly every other place in between. Some things have changed: back in those days, I didn’t much care whether I changed clothes every day or not, but I do now. Nevertheless, that trip taught me to pack light and learn to like it. Here are my rules for a road trip.

Rule #1: Pack light. No, lighter than that. If you can’t carry it yourself, don’t bring it. Unless you are going off-road in the Yukon, there are stores out there that sell most of what you might need beyond the basics. I even like to pack cheap or worn-out socks and T-shirts that I can discard when they’re dirty, making room for things I have acquired on the road. So you’re out in Utah without the exact headband or conditioner you would use at home! Who cares? You also won’t have to spend any time sorting, classifying, and packing and repacking those things. Having a light load frees you up both mentally and physically.

Rule #2: Know what you want to eat, and have it with you in the car. Otherwise, you end up at gas station shops buying Pringles when you really should have had bananas and nonfat yogurt. A small cooler is worth any weight and space it takes up.

Rule #3: Have a carefully crafted route and plan, and then be prepared to deviate from it regularly. This means maps and atlases, not just a nav system, so you have the resources to see the big picture and change your route intelligently when you spot an interesting detour. (See our related article on the latest in road atlas technology.)

Jean Jennings: Packing Genius

After three decades of traveling to places as far-flung as Madagascar, China, and Abu Dhabi (only China was a real road trip…on motorcycles), I’m a packing genius.

The longest time actually spent in a car was the first of the three times I participated in the One Lap of America race. That first time was 9,000-plus miles with co-drivers Parnelli Jones The Great and off-road truck racer Walker Evans, but it was in a full-sized Dodge panel van (disguised as a Stroh Brewery delivery truck).
From that big adventure, I solidified these rules.

Rule #1: Always bring a map. If it is an interstate adventure, bring an atlas. You need perspective, you need emergency routes, you need to know where you are at all times, in relationship to the rest of the United States. And you must never put the map away while you are in the car. A passenger who can’t use a map is almost useless.

Rule #2: Pack light. The third One Lap of America completely refined my must-have road tripping list because it was in a Porsche 911. The frunk (short for front trunk—engine is in the rear) is deep, but it ain’t no minivan. One small duffel each for co-driver Hurley Haywood and me. He also needed the space behind the back seats for his racing suit and helmet, because we had racetrack segments all around the 5,000-plus-mile route.

Rule #3: Comfort items are essential. The 911’s back seatbacks flip down, allowing something smallish (like a memory foam pillow) on the seat before you flip the back down. You then have a surprising amount of room for other stuff, like a thin quilt or an Eddie Bauer summer-weight down comforter (mine has plaid nylon on one side and fake fur on the other) that can squish up really tightly. I also like earplugs and eyeshades to complete the sensory deprivation I need to get a good car nap. Plus, slip-on sheepskin slippers with road soles.
Rule #3B: Bring an iPad. It’s a comfort item, too. You can play games, read books, get e-mail, and check and maintain your social standing on the road.
If this sounds like I set myself up on the road like I’m staying in bed all weekend, well, yeah, I guess so! But don’t forget the map.

Molly Jean: Queen of the Road

On the longest road trip I have ever been on, we drove around Lake Superior, with four adults, four bikes, and camping gear in a Mercedes-Benz E350 wagon. We were so stuffed in that when we returned home we bought a van. I am now a firm believer that, for comfort, you need a vehicle big enough to bring everything you could possibly need with you. In that, I know I am the exact opposite kind of traveler from Laura and Jean. I wonder whether we should take a long road trip together and see what happens? Here are my rules:

Rule #1: Be overprepared. My technique is to leave nothing home. “Coffin” (car-top carrier) on top, bike rack in the trailer hitch, and stuffed to the gills inside. I try to make it so that if the brakes are slammed, heavy items will not kill the passengers. Otherwise, I fill it up. My goal is to keep the front passenger's footwell clear. It never happens.

Rule #2: Be flexible. We got the van stuck in the mud at a closed campground at one o'clock in the morning and had to unload the entire vehicle, including the bike rack, to lighten the load. A sense of humor is one of the many things you must bring with you on a road trip.

Rule #3: Bring an atlas of county maps. Along with a blanket and pillow, an eye shade, an iPod, and a bag of candy and gum, it’s one of the essentials that ride up front with me. If there are big roads, there are little roads nearby; why not take those instead whenever you can, and actually see something?

Annie White: Have Tent, Will Travel

Planning has never been my forte. I’m more of a fly-by-the-seat-of-my-pants kind of girl. As long as I’ve got a tent I’ve got a place to sleep, and that’s all the planning I need. Of course, this travel technique works best for the young and unattached and doesn’t go as well with a family or a strict schedule. But for now it’s working just fine.

My longest road trip to date was an 1,800-mile jaunt from the Oregon coast to Yosemite National Park and back again. Salty snacks, good music, swims in ocean streams, nights spent under the stars—that trip had it all.
Rule #1: Think before you pack. My mother always told me to make a list when packing for any trip, and even though I almost never do it, I recognize that it’s good advice.

I resist the urge to overpack by laying everything out before I stuff it in bags, then doing a second pass to eliminate unnecessary items. As long as I am physically capable of carrying all my baggage at once, I know I’ve done good work.
Rule #2: Keep it light. I learned a long time ago that the only things you really need when traveling are a toothbrush, a few pairs of clean underwear, and maybe a first aid kit.
Rule #3: Bonus points for electronics. It’s worth the weight to have a phone (with charger) and a solid playlist (no mopey music allowed).

Gabrielle George: Catching the Joy as It Flies

The longest road trip I've taken was five hours north, to Mackinac Island in northern Michigan during high school. My friends and I felt ready, prepared, and safe. We all took turns driving when a person felt like she wanted a rest. We stopped at rest stops and jumped around, got drinks, went to the bathroom then off on the road again. Nothing more than loud music, obnoxious singing, windows down, energies high, and spirits lifted. I did the navigation, Alice fed me cheesy Combos, and I handed Hayley our classic childhood snack, Gushers. Five hours later, we hit the dock. It was time to park our mini house of snacks and luggage and take the ferry boat off to the world where no cars are allowed. After the long weekend, we headed back to Ann Arbor. We continued eating Combos and watching the little blue dot on my iPhone go straight through the state of Michigan. I would totally do that again. Next stop... Canada.

Rule #1: Make lists and more lists. I'm all about to-do lists. They're the one thing that works completely. I usually forget less when I have my handy-dandy journal of to-do lists and goals. I sync the lists with my iPad, iPhone, and laptop. When planning for a trip, I’ll make a packing list, a list of places to visit, a list of phone numbers and contacts…the list of lists is endless.

Rule #2: Create a personal set of road essentials. Mine traditionally includes Pepperidge Farm Goldfish and iced tea, plus Dramamine whenever I take a trip out of town. Last but surely not least, I'll definitely always need my camera right by my side the whole time.

Rule #3: Watch out for the small stuff. The number-one thing that I always lose in my luggage is memory cards. You have to keep a close eye on those, plus small but pivotal items such as lens caps, bobby pins, and chargers, so that you don’t lose them on a trip.
So we've got to ask: What's your packing style?

Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
This article first appeared in the January 1990 issue of Automobile Magazine. To see how Stirling, now Sir Stirling Moss, looks and sounds right now, see my video interview shot earlier this spring.


Cortina d’Ampezzo—I admit I was a little nervous, so I called my friend Pat Moss, the great rally champion, for a bit of advice.
“I’m doing that weeklong vintage rally across Europe in June with your brother,” I told her.

“Oh, Christ!” she laughed. “Stirling’s sense of humor is a little slow. You’ll have to go notch-notch with him. And he’s a terrifying driver,” teased the sister of one of the greatest racing drivers in history.

Actually, I wasn’t worried about the driving. At fifty-nine years old, the great Moss was still great. But I’d heard that he was a real bear—a persnickety, cranky, demanding perfectionist—with a boundless appreciation for the opposite sex.
It was all true.

Pirelli, in its unparalleled enthusiasm for motorsports, was for the second year sponsoring this epic 2,000-mile marathon across Europe in pre-1965 rally cars. Just over 100 teams from seven countries had entered their Jaguars and MGs and Austin-Healeys. There were several Ford Lotus-Cortinas, Sunbeam Rapiers and Tigers and Alpines, a couple of Volvo PV544s, some Rileys, two Jowett Jupiters, three Lancia Aurelia B20s, and a stunning Lancia Aprilia. There were also a Healey Silverstone, a Swallow Doretti, a Ferrari 275GTB, and a 1934 Talbot 105.

To guarantee a rousing battle, Pirelli had signed up five of the most famous names in rallying—Timo Makinen, Roger Clark, Ove Andersson, Paddy Hopkirk, and Stirling Moss—to participate. Among them, the now-graying famous five had won forty-three World and European Championship Rallies and sixteen Grands Prix (guess who). To undercore his genius on the open road, Stirling had also won the Targa Florio and the Mille Miglia and was one of only two drivers in history to have won a gold Alpine Cup for finishing three successive Alpine Rallies with no road penalties. My driver.

Our biggest drawback would be the car, a sweet little 1965 MGB roadster with an 1,800-cc engine, prepared by British MG specialist and vintage racing driver Ron Gammons. How could we possibly compete against the mighty 4.2-liter E-type Jaguars and the blistering Mini Coopers?

“I tell you, I bloody well want to win this thing,” Stirling shouted back to me. I was hanging on for dear life as we sped across London on his moped, along the Thames to the Tower Bridge, where our car was waiting at a press conference.
People pointed to us from the sidewalk, and you could see their moths say, “Stirling Moss.” Cabbies yelled to him at red lights: “Hey, Stirling! I remember the Cooper!”

I had stayed up pretty late looking through our two-volume route book. In the next seven days we would have to check in on time at seventy-seven controls stretching across seven countries, from London to Cortina d’Ampezzo in the Italian Alps, with a loop through Yugoslavia. We would be driving many of the most famous roads and mountain passes of the brutal Liege-Rome-Liege and the Alpine Rallies of the 1950s and early 1960s. There would be seven special timed speed sections including a lap of the Nurburgring, a visit to Hockenheim, and three hill-climbs. From all appearances, there were few opportunities for Stirling’s driving skill to win position and seventy-seven chances for me to get us lost, check in late, and blow it.

Sunday

We started seventh in the sea of people and cars that crowded the Tower Bridge at 7:30 a.m., waving adieu to Stirling’s wife, Susie, and eight-year-old son, Elliot. Barely out of London and Stirling was waving to a carful of young cuties. I looked at him sternly, and he laughed.
“You can pick up a nice wife that way,” he explained.

Our first destination was an abandoned Hoverport on the coast where we would run a gymkhana before boarding the channel ferry for Dunkirk. One little twist at the end that would handicap us for the rest of the rally was the proviso that the co-driver had to leap from the car and hit a red button on the timing table to arrest the time clock. I am no lithe, limber, leaping sprite. Especially not in a five-point safety harness. We placed eleventh, beaten by Paddy Hopkirk in his Mini Cooper, Timo Makinen in his Victor Gauntlett-owned Austin-Healey 3000, two other Austin-Healeys and another Mini, a Lotus-Cortina, a Jaguar E-type, a Triumph Vitesse, and two other MGBs. What we could not abide was that one of those MGBs was our team owner, Ron Gammons, who was clearly out of his skull with joy for having beaten the great Moss. Small consolation that we pipped Roger Clark’s Cortina by a second.

There wasn’t a big sulk across France and Belgium, but Stirling was not going to let this happen again. We might not win overall, but he wasn’t going to be beaten by an identical car. He made me look up the next test, tomorrow morning’s run through a Belgian park, and decipher the course.

pages.name: page2

pageElements.text:
Monday

We lined up behind Mike McCarthy, editor in chief of Britain’s Classic and Sportscar and co-driver/photographer Julian Mackie. Their ’55 Austin-Healey 100-Four was acting up, and they promised to keep out of our way if we caught them on the course.

Stirling and our MGB were flawless, flicking through the haybale chicanes and pivoting around an impossible hairpin that circled a huge oak. We caught our friends from Classic and Sportscar, and they dove for the ditch so we could race past. I had the belts off and the door open the minute I caught sight of the time clock and slapped the red button as fast as I could manage. We smoked everyone around us and found out later that only the number 75 Austin-Healey 3000 of John Chatham was faster. We also noted that we tied for second with the number 107 Ford Lotus-Cortina of Piggy Thompson and Eddie Ganderton, who had knocked down the fastest penalty-free run at the Hoverport. We’d beaten Paddy by a second and Ron Gammons by fourteen seconds. Timo’s Austin-Healey blew a fuel pump fuse and died on the course for five minutes.

Stirling beamed as we sped along deserted two-lanes, descending from the Ardennes to Haccourt, following signs to Liege. We crossed into West Germany and, as we climbed into the Eifel Mountains, saw our first sign for the Nurburgring.
We planned to ace the Nurburgring. Who better than ringmeister Stirling Moss? As it turned out, a whole bunch of people once we’d bungled the reversing test.

The Nurburgring test began with a backward run through a slalom course, a sly attempt by the organizers to keep the rally’s average speed down to the sanctioning body’s strict 35-mph average. Our problems began when Stirling headed for the wrong side of the first cone, a twenty-second penalty. I yelled for him to go the other way, and it took forever to sort it all out. If it weren’t for Stirling’s knowledge of the track (he described each turn in advance as he flew around), we would have finished much worse than thirteenth fastest. The number 75 Austin-Healey was in front again, sharing fast lap with Paddy Hopkirk’s Mini Cooper. And this time, not only Ron Gammons but his son Malcolm in the third MGB of our Bees’ Knees team beat our time.

The next test—at Hockenheim—wasn’t until the following morning. Our enjoyment of the winding route along the Moselle, and of the forest roads we traveled between the two legendary circuits, was woefully dampened.

“We’ll gradually have to lower our sights just to keep morale up in the car,” moaned Stirling. “First, it was an overall win. Then first in class. Now it’s team prize and an Alpine Cup.” We had laughed at that, and somehow the day brightened.

Tuesday

We were tenth fastest at Hockenheim, but Roger Clark’s Lotus-Cortina conked out for a spell midway around the circuit, so we moved up a notch (with John and Alison Woolley’s Triumph Vitesse) to sixth overall. Timo’s Austin-Healey was healed, setting fast time by two seconds, but his previous electrical problems had dumped him in less-than-threatening sixty-sixth place overall.

Very soon the rally would become brutal, and we’d have a chance to fight our way back. But for now, as we drove across rural Germany, the hills were small, and the sky was so blue it looked fake. Stirling prayed for rain as we got our first real glimpse of the Alps from Fussen. We had 100 miles of serious snow-capped peaks before we reached our stop for the night in Merano, Italy. The last was the Passo del Rombo, at 8,232 feet, with an Italian customs booth at the top. It was the first (but not the last) time Stirling’s driving style really grabbed my attention. He had been flying along, which doesn’t bother me, and to save the brakes in the mountains, he had been using the throttle and steering wheel rather flamboyantly in concert with the understeer. That didn’t bother me. The Passo Del Rombo bothered me.
First, he didn’t believe me when I told him customs was a mere half-kilometer ahead of us, around one of those blind turns.
“Any second now!” I yelled.
“Stirling!” I yelled.
He hadn’t begun to lift when we crested the hill and saw the guards in their little booth, handing passports back to some other rallyists.

“Shit!” yelled Stirling, throwing us into a slide to scrub off speed.  The guards took one look at the rally car sliding toward their shelter and hit the floor. We were still sliding when their peaked caps came up, then eyes, then arms waving us frantically past.

“Go, go, go!” I hollered, and we were heading down the other side. Which scared me worse. There were the dark, narrow, slimy tunnels. There was a tiny road slashing back and forth down the mountain, so narrow that at one point a truck had to reverse for a half-mile to let a bus past. There were the carabinieri, chasing us in a Land Rover, which didn’t stop Stirling from passing Paddy’s Mini Cooper on a piece of road barely big enough for both cars. Navigator Alec Poole was at the wheel.
“It’s good to do that, even if Paddy wasn’t driving,” said Stirling. “It’s a mental thing.”
I said nothing.
“And anyway, I enjoyed it, so sod that.” He began singing something Italian in an exaggerated basso profundo, speeding up from 70 kph to 90.

“You’re not a nervous passenger, are you?” he said without looking. “Because if you are, I feel sorry for you.” He thought that was pretty funny. Even funnier were the carabinieri, who finally caught us at the bottom of the hill and passed us with very big smiles and waves. Stirling passed them back.

I was actually becoming used to Stirling’s aversion to following other cars. It wasn’t the passing that took adjustment as much as the shouting and waving that accompanied every single pass. If the party to be overtaken moved over promptly, he was rewarded with a hand wave from Stirling. Any resistance and Stirling would lay on the horn, wave his fist menacingly, and shout insults as he went by. He shocked the Germans and the Austrians, but we were in Italy now, and they loved it, especially his rude Italian. He loved it, too.

pages.name: page3

pageElements.text:
Wednesday

The rally reseeded Wednesday morning in Merano, with the fast cars at the front of the pack—even Timo, who the organizers decided to start twentieth “in the interest of safety,” despite his fifty-eighth-place position. The order now went: John Chatham’s Austin-Healey, Piggy Thompson’s Cortina, the E-type of Henry Pearman, Paddy’s Mini, and our archrival for first in class 6b, Tony Dron in another MGB. We were seventeen seconds back, still tied with the Woolleys' Vitesse.

Paddy strolled over as we waited for the day to begin. “Stirling, you know old John Chatham over there fancies himself quite the driver,” he said. We all looked at the ruddy-faced Chatham, enjoying his fame as the rally leader.

“Why don’t you go over and ask for his autograph? That’ll get him bothered, and he’ll run off the road straight away.” Paddy’s co-driver was holding out a pen and a vintage racing magazine with Chatham’s Austin-Healey on the cover, and somehow, I was the one coerced into doing the dirty deed. Chatham was quite obliging, and the jinx was on in Paddy’s devilish Irish eyes.

Four of rallying’s greatest mountain passes were planned for this day: the Stelvio, the Gavia, the Vivione, and the Croce Dominii. The Stelvio would be a closed-road hill-climb, uphill only, which would favor the stronger cars.

As hyped as I was to be racing up the famous Stelvio, it was pretty uneventful. Left. Right. Left. Right. More exciting than the drive was seeing forth-place Paddy along the way, leaning against his dead Mini. But the true excitement happened on the way down. Not to us, but to Roger and Margaret Ealand in a lovely red 1965 E-type Jaguar.

Mr. and Mrs. Ealand had had quite a ball running up the Stelvio, and at the top, Mister confided to Missus that this was for him. Yes, he would be pursuing this type of adventure from here on. Ten kilometers later, marked in the route book as “first of many tunnels. CARE—some very narrow,” they crashed heavily, mangling their pretty Jag. Rally officials nearby helped them move the car from the tunnel and to the side of the road, which also happened to be the side of the cliff. A flatbed truck came by, and as the truck driver and Mr. Ealand attempted to pull the Jaguar aboard, Mr. Ealand’s rope snapped, and he pitched off the side of the cliff. Mrs. Ealand fainted dead away. Thankfully, Mr. Ealand's fifty-foot plunge left him merely bruised and shaken.

While the drama of the E-type was unfolding behind us, we headed for the Gavia. After a mad scramble for fuel (during which Stirling had to shout in Italian at two gas stations' worth of attendants to get served during off hours), we found our road—a tiny, barely paved piece of nothing wriggling up through the forest and bounded by a thin little wooden slat guardrail. Except where it was missing.

We came around one bend and were stopped cold by an eathmover completely blocking the way. Stirling leapt from the car and, wasting no niceties, shouted in Italian, the gist of which was “important race,” “no time,” and probably a few motivational words learned from his race mechanics back in the old days. I was mortified. They shouted back. He shouted louder. They caved in. We were through.

We hit the Passo di Gavia summit—a spectacular expanse of high snow fields with a 360-degree view of jagged mountain ranges—at a dead run. The road down was disintegrating, and we banged and rattled at speed over the rough terrain. With seventeen minutes and six kilometers left to our checkpoint, Stirling plotted how to arrive with just enough time to clock in with the front-runners straggling behind us. Piggy Thompson’s Lotus-Cortina was the only car in front of us as we headed for a series of tunnels.

They were a nasty lot, especially at the speed we were traveling. He chose a tunnel in which to pass the Cortina, horn-blasting trucks, cars, and road graders out of our path, veering to the wrong side of a roadworks sign through what felt like thick mud. Later, we discovered we’d churned through wet cement.

Our first “selective” test was a regular run over roads open to the public, with the exception that we had to clock in to the exact second on our due minute, with a penalty point for every second late. I looked at the rally computer as we were flagged off, and there were no mileage readings. Striling looked at his gauges,  and there was no odometer. We looked at each other and swore in our native tongues. Nothing could be worse, we thought. It could.

We had to drive fifty-five kilometers through small villages, negotiate the Passo di Vivione, and descend to Borno. It was another slash back and forth through the mountains, and on the way up to Vivione, we passed leader Chatham’s Austin-Healey stuffed into the mountainside. He waved, and I felt a twinge. Paddy’s autograph jinx.
I didn’t have time to worry. We had our own problems. Stirling tapped the temperature gauge with his finger. The needle was spun completely around. He patted the steering wheel.

“Good old girl,” he said, coaxing her up the mountain. We expected the ride down to cool the engine, but the needle stayed pegged. A well by the side of the road caught Stirling’s eye, and he pulled off. There were two wine jugs, and I filled them as Stirling wrenched the radiator cap free. We poured the water in and then checked under the car. There was no leak. There was no water coming from the exhaust. We were stymied, and when the needle hit the peg again, we knew our problem was terminal.

Again we found a roadside well, and the radiator took all the water we could pour in. Mystified, downcast, we continued on in silence. We made it to our checkpoint on time and decided to wait for Ron Gammons, a few cars behind us, to have a look. The clerk of the course, famed navigator in his own right Fred Gallagher, looked under the hood with us.
“No fanbelt,” he said.

What a couple of bozos. Ron arrived and hooked up a new belt. Fred’s wife poured her drinking water into our radiator, and we were on our way, temperature needle settled at ninety, and Alpine Cup still intact.

We crossed the Passo di Croce Dominii, and it was one narrow donkey village after another back to Merano. With the demise of poor Chatham and Paddy (who continued, but in ninety-first place), we were now in third behind Henry Pearman’s E-type and the Lotus-Cortina of Piggy Thompson. Dron was three seconds back. Timo had moved up an astounding forty-four positions to twenty-second place.

pages.name: page4

pageElements.text:
Thursday

The rain that we had been praying for materialized as we climbed to the Passo di Monte Giovo. The road twisted up through dark pines, their new growth fluorescent against the gray sky. It was sprinkling as we descended into the fog-shrouded valley below.
“This is quite like the descent to Adenau at the Nurburgring,” observed Stirling.
Our speed picked up.
“Saving the brakes,” he said.

It would be a hard day of mountaineering—we faced the Passo di Pennes after the Monte Giovo, then the passi Lavaze, Rolle, Cereda, Duran, and Cibiana. The rain-slicked narrow roads really cheered Stirling, and the old stories came hot and heavy, in between downshifts, singing, and yelling in Italian at numerous road construction crews. One roadblock five kilometers from our checkpoint seemed particularly impassable. A big earthmover was in the middle of a major operation when Stirling began yelling at the foreman.

“Twenty minutes,” said the foreman in Italian, as Stirling hopped up and in the front of him. Back and forth the shouting went, when Stirling suddenly spun on his heel and hurried back to our car. He sailed past the long line of waiting traffic, inserted himself at the front of the line, yelled more out the window, and the machine miraculously dropped its load and backed out of the way.
“Heh-heh-heh,” laughed Stirling as he pushed the MGB around the sheer rock face that bordered the one-lane path.  “Oh, I love it!” We checked in on time.
Our only test for the day was another timed-to-the-second selective section, encompassing the last three passes. Two girls were hitchhiking from the summit of Cereda.
“Can you navigate?” Stirling yelled to them as we flew by. I socked him.
We followed the E-Type up the last major climb of the day—Cibiana.
“I don’t really want to pass him,” said Stirling, “but I have to get on my brakes to avoid hitting him in the corners.”
“Well, drop back then and save the brakes,” I said.
“Then again, if we push him, he might shunt,” said Stirling. “Hee-hee-hee.” He backed off and looked at me. “I’m a terrible sport.”
Not much farther on, we came upon the E-Type, parked at the side with a flat tire.
“Can we help?” asked Stirling, slowing. They waved us on.
As we waited for our exact second to roll up, the Jaguar came screaming into the checkpoint. On time.
“Oh, bugger!” said Stirling, “Bugger, bugger, bugger!”

Our gas station looked grim for the run into Cortina, so Stirling decided to coast down the mountain. The hairpins were a little tricky, but we rolled down at a fair clip, only slightly off the pace of the Triumph in front of us.
“It’s rather restful, isn’t it?” asked Stirling. “How far do you reckon we can coast?”

Not all the way to our checkpoint in Cortina, unfortunately. First we ran out of mountain, then fuel. Then we realized that our fuel filler was in the trunk, especially safe from vandals now that the trunk latch was broken. I ran like hell back down the road and waved Ron Gammons over as he came flying by. With a mighty whack of a very large hammer and screwdriver, he punched through the worthless lock, wrenched open our trunk lid, gave us a can of fuel, and sped off. Once again, we checked in on time.

pages.name: page5

pageElements.text:
Friday

There were no hill-climbs or special tests today, but one of those special selective sections, this one in Yugoslavia. We had come to realize that we couldn’t gain any position on these sections, only throw our Alpine Cup away, and we had come perilously close to doing so.

The sky was still heavy with rain when we left for Yugoslavia over the Dolomites, and the dark sky suited the Italian mountain villages. It also suited the mood of the E-type crew as it worked to change yet another flat tire, this one within yards of the day’s first checkpoint.

Kranjska Gora, just over the border into Yugoslavia, was swarming with British tourists, who swarmed Stirling while I changed five bucks into fifty zillion pazooties and bought us coffee that tasted like dirty socks.

Our selective was another horror, this time a hill-climb up twenty-four cobbled hairpins (open to the public), to the fabled Moistrocca summit. It was a busy day for the tourist bus trade; we passed seven going up and made it with twenty seconds to spare.

Back in Cortina d’Ampezzo, we washed our faithful mount as three ancient Italian crones in black sipped espresso nearby. One toddled over, handbag clutched over her arm, pointed to Stirling’s name on the side of the car, and pointed to my driver as he toweled the car. I nodded; she beamed and pulled a camera from her bag.

Saturday

“I called my son last night,” said Stirling over breakfast. “I said, ‘Elliot, Daddy and Jeannie are lying third overall.’ He said, ‘Oh, Daddy! You’ll just have to try harder!’ Isn’t that cute?”

And we tried like hell, beginning our last circuit of the Dolomites with the Giau hill-climb. We turned the same time as the second-place Cortina, while the Jaguar (which had suffered three flats the day before) played safe. Timo blew us all in the weeds, climbing from seventeenth place to seventh in the process. We maintained our slim lead over Tony Dron’s MGB, but when Piggy told us that he had rejetted the Cortina’s carburetor, we knew it would take a miracle to better our position. Before ten in the morning, we had climbed four major mountain passes over icy roads, past waterfalls, and above the clouds that sunk over jagged peaks into the valleys below. Passo di Sella lay more than a dozen hairpins up another of those roads guarded by thin wooden slats. We slid wide on the ice at one point, and Stirling got the MGB stopped against one of the worthless rails. We looked at each other, my breath coming a little faster.
“I thought we were going to nudge it” was all he said as he backed away and roared on.

We had one test left: the climb from Lago di Misurina up to Tre Cime di Lavaredo. Everyone’s last chance, and everyone took it. The top three teams—the Jaguar of Henry Pearman and Gordon Cruickshank, Piggy Thompson and Eddie Ganderton in the Cortina, and our stalwart MGB—turned identical times and finished the rally one-two-three. The Bees’ Knees won the team prize, with Ron Gammons finishing sixth and son Malcolm in fifteenth. We had won our cups.

But Timo Makinen was the real hero of the day, delivering another blistering performance in his mighty Austin-Healey that edged him, finally, into sixth place overall. The BBC interviewed him at the finish. “What was it like getting back into the old Healey?” they asked.
“Well, it were very hard to get back into,” joked the now-rotund Finn.
And the other stories rolled around us as we stopped for a barbecue in the spitting snow.
Roger Clark had cracked a raw egg into his radiator to plug a leak.
Kate Manley-Tucker had to back up her 1948 Allard M-type nine times on the Stelvio’s hairpins.
Paddy Hopkirk, the world’s largest manufacturer of gas cans, had run out of gas with no spare fuel aboard.
So had Henry Pearman in the winning Jaguar. And the team battling him for the lead, Piggy Thompson and Eddie Ganderton, stopped and gave him fuel.
We had only to check in at Cortina to finish, an anticlimactic run back to town.
“Well done, old girl,” said Stirling.
“Well done, Stirling,” I replied.
Henry Pearman and Gordon Cruickshank beamed as they blew champagne out over the crowd surrounding the finish line. Stirling and I waved from our perch on the roof of the MGB.
“We need an E-type for next year,” he said.

metaDescription: Wit and Wisdom of the Moss-Carlssons: a classic book, sadly out of print. Here are some snippets, on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Pat Moss and Erik Carlsson were rallying royalty. Pat, whose story we’ve told in our Notorious Women series, was the younger sister of Stirling Moss (more about him here and here). She was a ladies’ champion in rallying, and she married Erik Carlsson, a rally driver for Saab who was one of the first inducted into the Rally Hall of Fame. What better couple to write a book on driving technique? Which they did.

Their classic book The Art and Technique of Driving, published in 1965, is unfortunately out of print. There are definitely parts that are quaint (“There is no proof that car radios cause accidents….if you do decide to have one, it must be fitted properly by an expert”), but so much in this book is solid, wise advice that somebody really ought to get this back into print. Because really, wouldn’t you love to have these two sitting in the car with you, giving you advice about techniques they honed in the Alps?
Here are some of our favorite parts.

On Being a Good (or Bad) Driver

“Although we can assume that nearly all slow drivers are bad, we cannot assume that nearly all bad drivers are slow.”

“One of the best tests of a good driver is passenger reaction. A normal passenger who is able to drive should stop reaching for his footbrake after five minutes. Your driving should make him feel relaxed and safe by that time.”
“The simple and obvious truth about cornering is that good drivers do it safely and bad drivers do not.”

“Both of us are bad passengers and seem to suffer unduly from bad drivers. A lot of people start showing off as soon as they know you are a competition driver. They want to prove that they could have been world champions if they had been given the chance, so they go wild and take terrible risks…One of the worst examples was in America when a taxi-driver recognized us and started driving like mad over a wet, slippery road. Suddenly the car went broadside and for some strange reason both the rear doors flew open. We cowered in the back clutching at the seats and at each other to keep from falling out as the taxi went sideways down the street. The driver had his own way of dealing with the situation. He put all the blame on the cab and shouted at it: ‘Now then, Rosemary! That’s no way to behave.’ ”

On Being Physically Comfortable in the Car

“You should try to be physically relaxed while driving, and it is quite possible to do this while remaining mentally alert…We both have some experience of racing as well as rallying, and we can assure you that a racing driver who was physically tense and who clutched at the wheel would not have the sensitivity to drive the car fast round corners. The heart of a surgeon during a difficult operation probably beats as fast as the heart of a racing driver during a difficult race, but no one has ever suggested that a surgeon should hold his scalpel in the tight, feelingless grip of a boy whittling a stick. Good surgery and good driving both need a light sensitive touch.”

On Reading the Road

"Anticipation is one of the most valuable assets for good driving. The classic example was something which happened during the Monaco Grand Prix race in 1950. This race is run through the streets of Monte Carlo, and it was won that year by [Juan Manuel] Fangio, one of the best racing drivers of all time…He was roaring around the circuit in his Alfa Romeo and as he approached a tricky corner he suddenly noticed that there was something different about the crowd. It did not look the same as usual. There was not the normal whitish blur of faces.

“Fangio braked hard. He realized that if the faces were not white, then the people in the crowd were not looking towards him. They were looking away from him at something more interesting. Fangio went round the corner more slowly than usual—and around it there was a tremendous pileup of racing cars. If he had been going at normal speed he would have crashed into them…The effect of good observation and interpretation in normal road driving can be just as dramatic and as important to the driver.”

“Observation comes first and interpretation follows...A driver traveling at 30 mph in town is able to notice events and movements in his immediate vicinity because his eyes are adjusted for what might be called close work. At 70 or 80 mph, a driver’s eyes are focused to observe things 200 or 300 or even 400 yards away. He is slow to notice things happening just a few feet from his car…The driver who thinks correctly will be able to appreciate the various and sometimes obscure possibilities of any particular traffic situation and to interpret his observations.”

On Dealing with Other Drivers

“Some people seem to regard it as their duty to ensure that no other motorist exceeds the speed limit. Some other people are genuinely worried about whether they can be charged with aiding and abetting a crime if they allow someone to overtake at 50 mph in a 40-mph zone.

“Our advice to all these people is: If someone exceeding the speed limit wants to go past, then pull over and let him through. A driver who is unable to obey the law and keep within the speed limit may also be bumptious, overbearing, bad-tempered, and an appalling driver. So you should do everything in your power to see that there is as big a distance as possible between his car and yours.”

On Rallying

“Fog is probably the motorist’s worst enemy. Everybody hates it, including the authors. Nevertheless we have been quoted in newspapers once or twice as saying that we wanted fog on a particular rally. We admit that we did say so. We do like fog on rallies. The reason is that all cars are reduced to roughly the same speed…Our Saab cars have quite small engines, so fog on a rally is an advantage to us...”

“There is really only one piece of advice that we can give to anyone who is preparing to try some competition driving. It is: Speed matters, and the longer your foot is on the brake the less it is on the accelerator.”

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: New cars are packed with technology most of us couldn’t have imagined ten years ago. This is good news for tech-savvy early adopters, but for the rest of us, all these new functions can be overwhelming. For the owners of new Ford vehicles, the learning process is about to get a little easier.

Ford has just launched a new video orientation program, which makes use of short instructional videos (Ford is calling them “video snacks”) to help consumers discover the potential in their new cars. New owners will go over a list of features with their salesperson when they purchase their car and decide which features they’d like to receive guidance on via the short videos Ford has created. The customer will then receive an e-mail with links to the videos they wanted to see, which they can then watch at their leisure and as often as necessary until they feel comfortable with their car’s technology. Customers can also single out car features that they would like to discuss with a salesperson on delivery of their car, what they’d like to talk about during a Sync My Ride session, and topics they’d rather not cover at all.

Ninety Ways to Explore Your Ford

Ford has created more than ninety of the videos, choosing topics based on the questions new owners ask on online forums most frequently. Topics range from technology like My Key, which allows parents to limit a car’s functions when a teen is driving, to simple instructions like how to operate a car’s electronic parking brake.

The company hopes that the short videos will allow customers to master their new car’s features on their own time instead of attempting to absorb all that information in one visit to the dealership. The videos could be considered a little cheesy by some, but they’re undeniably informative and easy to follow. Ford has also posted the videos to the “Know Your Vehicle” playlist on its Ford Owner YouTube channel, allowing current owners can reap the benefits without having to make a return trip to the dealership.
