pageElements.text: Lamborghini turns fifty this year, and the Italian exotic-car maker is (not surprisingly) going over the hill with a bang.

At the Shanghai Auto Show next week, the company will unveil a special edition of its Aventador supercar. The Aventador LP720-4 50° Anniversario will have a run of only 100 vehicles and can use its astounding 720-horsepower 6.5-liter V-12 engine to propel the car from 0 to 60 mph in less than three seconds.
Blistering power is all well and good, but what will it look like standing still?

Glittering Giallo

This special edition will be a vision in yellow—or, more specifically, Giallo Maggio (May yellow), a brand-new paint color meant to reference Lamborghini’s founding in May 1963 and the historical preference that its customers have for yellow exteriors. Lamborghini assures us that the color will have a “particularly intense glitter effect,” so you may have to pull out your shades in the unlikely event that you spot one of these ultra-exclusive supercars cruising around town.

The interior will be similarly eye-catching in black and brown (or black and yellow) leather. What shade of yellow? you may ask. It's Giallo Quercus, which harmonizes with the exterior. It's named for the yellow oak tree displayed in the coat of arms of Sant’Agata Bolognese, Lamborghini's home town.

Even if Lamborghinis aren’t quite your cup of tea, you can’t deny the superior craftsmanship at work here. The semi-aniline leather was developed especially for the LP720-4 and preserves the material’s natural grain and textures. A special diamond stitch pattern was also introduced for this model, a further celebration of the fine Italian craftsmanship at work.

Exterior tweaks to this special Aventador include performance-oriented changes to the front and rear fascias, which will also help careful observers distinguish this triumph of machinery from Lamborghini’s more run-of-the-mill masterpieces.
No word on price, but if you have to ask…and the 100 customers who will be able to buy this limited edition most certainly don't.

title: Motorcycle Safety: A Rite of Spring
subTitle: Five ways to share the road safely with motorcycles.
promoTitle: Motorcycle Safety: A Rite of Spring
promoTeaserSmall: Five ways to share the road safely with motorcycles.
promoTeaser: Five ways to share the road safely with motorcycles.
keywords: Motorcycle Safety: A Rite of Spring
metaTitle: Motorcycle Safety: A Rite of Spring - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Motorcycle Safety: A Rite of Spring is the JeanKnowsCars.com guide to five ways you can be a safer driver around motorcycles. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: We’ve been saying it for weeks, so it must be true: spring is here. And that means that motorcyclists will once again be taking to the roads to bask in the warm weather. For the drivers of passenger vehicles, this means that some extra care is required to keep everyone safe. We’ve gathered a few tips about motorcycle safety to help you share the road effectively with our motorcycle-driving brethren.

1. Pay Attention

One of the Allstate’s first tips for sharing the road with motorcyclists is to look both ways to check for bikers. Motorcycles can hide in blind spots or blend in at intersections. Always make sure that you are fully aware of your surroundings and look for motorcycles before you change lanes or cross an intersection.

2. No Tailgating

This is good advice no matter whom you’re driving behind, but since motorcycles are especially vulnerable, it counts double when you’re behind a biker. Pick a stationary object like a street sign or a tree and count the seconds between when the rider (or driver) ahead of you passes it and when your front tires go by. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) recommends three or four seconds of leeway between a car and the motorcycle it’s following. Maintaining a proper following distance will give you time to react in case of an emergency. Obviously, you can—and should—adjust the three-or-four-second rule if weather or visibility is bad.

3. Motorcycles May Be Closer Than They Appear

The Motorcycle Safety Foundation (MSF) notes that since motorcycles are small, they can appear to be farther away than they really are. Since they’re so maneuverable, they can appear to be moving more quickly than they are. Just like the warning on your side mirrors tell you, err on the side of caution and act as if the motorcycles on the road are closer than they appear. That means no cutting across an intersection if a motorcycle is approaching

4. Make Eye Contact

NHTSA and MSF also noted that motorcycles don’t have the self-canceling turn signals that car drivers take for granted, so if you see a motorcycle with its turn signal blinking, keep in mind that the rider may have just forgotten to turn the signal off after a previous turn. Make eye contact with motorcyclists before you turn toward them at intersections, just to be sure you’re both aware.

5. Do What You (Should) Always Do

This should go without saying, but be courteous when sharing the road with motorcyclists (and bicyclists and other cars). Bikers have much less room for error than the drivers of enclosed automobiles, so give them a break. Don’t drive aggressively when you’re sharing their road space or cut them off. Use your turn signals and don’t make sudden lane changes or turns. Basically, drive the way you should be driving anyway.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: The best thing about Michigan winters is the sensation of slipping into flannel sheets at the end of the day. If you have never slept in a cold house with flannel sheets, or if you are a flannel hater, read no further. I have a shopping tip to share with flannel lovers. It is a bit pricey, but my hands say it is worth every penny.

The 2013 Porsche Cayenne GTS steering wheel is wrapped in Alcantara—a fabulous composite material that has the look and feel of suede but apparently has better durability. I would have never imagined that the feel of a steering wheel would be the biggest impression left after driving a $137,000 vehicle.

When I first caught sight of this vermilion beauty in the parking lot, I was taken by its shade of red. I have never been a fan of red cars. When I think of red cars, visions of mid-1980s Pontiacs pop into my mind. But this Cayenne’s red is sublime. Think red barns, juicy red apples, sweet raspberries. The official name is Carmine Red, which comes with an upcharge of $3,140. But with a base price of $83,025, who's counting pennies?

A Great Hour

The dash is also wrapped in luscious Alcantara. But it gets better: it has red stitching and red seatbelts, all details courtesy of two interior packages at an additional $7,105. I was only in the Cayenne for an hour, but I must say it was a great hour. This is the first SUV that I have driven that felt like a sports car. It was a bit scary to think that in some parts of the country, I could buy a house for the price of this vehicle. But the whole time I was driving, I was distracted by the Alcantara. As I drove, I kept moving my hands around on the steering wheel because it felt so damn good.
Mother’s Day is right around the corner, and nothing says love like a juicy-red, flannel-lined Porsche Cayenne.

pageElements.text: The next time you hail a cab in New York City, it could be a very different experience from the taxi rides of the past. Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced on Earth Day that the city’s taxi fleet will be joined by six all-electric Nissan Leafs as a part of a yearlong pilot program that Bloomberg hopes will provide insight into how electric vehicles can be integrated into taxi fleets in the future.

Starting with Six

The six silver-and-yellow pilot cabs will be driven by independent taxi drivers and fleet owners who have volunteered for the program and will be allowed to turn down fares, a nod to the limited driving range of electric vehicles.

The 2012 Leaf has an EPA-rated driving range of 106 miles in city driving. New York’s gridlock will likely maximize the Leaf’s range by providing plenty of opportunity for regenerative braking and rare cause to travel at battery-draining highway speeds.

How Are They Meeting the Charging Challenge?

The city will install three quick-charging stations that will allow drivers of the Leaf taxi to recharge up to 80 percent in just thirty minutes. Some of the drivers have electric charging stations at their homes to allow them to charge overnight, but it’s likely that the drivers will have to take time to replenish battery life during their shifts.

Target: 4,400 Electric Cabs by 2020

The pilot program starts just a few months before Nissan’s NV200 van becomes the official taxi of New York City. Mayor Bloomberg has said that he hopes electric vehicles will make up one-third of New York City’s taxi fleet by 2020. There are currently 13,237 yellow taxis in New York, so it would take roughly 4,440 electric cabs to meet that goal.

pageElements.text: We’ve known that Chevrolet was preparing an electric version of its tiny Spark for some time now, but details were hazy at best. Well, EV enthusiasts, the wait is finally over. General Motors unveiled range and efficiency numbers for its battery-powered electric vehicle today, and the news is good: with a combined city/highway rating of 119 MPGe, the Spark EV will be the most efficient electric vehicle for sale in the U.S. when it hits dealerships.

The Spark EV’s eighty-two miles of combined city/highway range is about what’s expected for an electric car this size, but the car’s newly released fuel economy ratings are something to write home about. Apparently not content that the Chevrolet Cruze Diesel, at 46 mpg on the highway, is the highest-rated non-hybrid passenger car for sale in the United States, Chevrolet has topped efficiency charts again with the Spark EV.

The tiny Spark EV wears essentially the same skin as its gas-sipping twin (although it sports wavy “energy” lines on the grille, à la the Chevrolet Volt, and a green EV badge on the rear), but under the hood, an internal-combustion engine is replaced by an electric motor that produces upward of 100 kilowatts of power—130 horsepower, in case you slept through physics class. The motor is powered by a 20-kWh, 560-pound battery pack that sits in front of the rear wheels, leaving cargo space untouched.
The Spark EV will go on sale in California and Oregon this summer.

pageElements.text: Ralph Gilles, who has been head of design at Chrysler since 2008, is one of the coolest of the cool designers in the business. He was a relative unknown in the design world until he jumped to center stage as the design spokesman for the 2005 Chrysler 300. His claim to fame was creating the production car design from the radical Dodge Super8 Hemi concept penned by Freeman Thomas, now head of Ford’s advanced design department. Few had heard of Ralph Gilles until then.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/egArJLXaDBQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

From the 300, Ralph designed the 2006 Charger sedan. It wasn’t as beautiful as the original Charger, but it had a lot of emotion, which was exactly what Chrysler needed in the dark days. After that, he came into his own and he has managed to swim to the top of Chrysler’s design food chain while maintaining his sparkling, off-the-wall personality.

He was such a golden boy that he was put in charge of the entire Dodge division (along with his chief designer duties) for a while, a very rare move that was pioneered by Cadillac when it installed designer Bryan Nesbitt as its chief for a short while. Neither of them lasted long in the Big Chair (the move from artist to businessman has just been a bridge too far in the auto world), although in 2011, Chrysler put Ralph in charge as president and CEO of its performance division, SRT. It totally suits his personality and his whole vibe, which includes walking around in black leather and maintaining a lively and controversial presence in the Twitterverse.
Follow him! @RalphGilles

2013 Chrysler 300SRT8

Vital Stats

Base price: $48,990 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 14 mpg city/23 mpg highway (with 6.4-liter Hemi V-8 engine and five-speed automatic transmission)
Standard safety features: Electronic stability control, traction control, electronic brake-force distribution, brake assist; optional SafetyTec group includes blind-spot, rear cross-path, and forward collision monitoring
Technology features: Comes standard with six-speaker Alpine premium audio, but there’s an optional nineteen-speaker Harman Kardon audio system; UConnect 8.4-inch touchscreen LED display with Garmin navigation
Chief competitors: BMW M5, Cadillac CTS-V, Lexus IS-F

Key Points

- The racy SRT version of the Chrysler 300 comes with a one-day SRT Track Experience, held at racetracks around the country to help drivers improve their skills on street or track
- Standard performance pages feature shows you 0-to-60 mph, eighth- and quarter-mile times, g-force, oil pressure, and more on a center color screen
- Luxury meets performance in a leather-wrapped steering wheel, heated and cooled cupholders, and LED ambient lighting, for example
- Class or brass: Black Nappa leather seats and Poltrona Foligno leather-wrapped instrument panel with French-seamed stitching are available, or you can go in a different direction and get red-and-black Nappa leather seats with perforated suede inserts and silver accent stitching

title: 2013 BMW M3: My Orange Crush
subTitle: How do you feel about a car this bright?
promoTeaserSmall: How do you feel about a car this bright?

metaTitle: 2013 BMW M3: My Orange Crush
metaDescription: 2013 BMW M3: My Orange Crush is the story of a Lime Rock Park limited edition of the M car, paired with the tale of a California dealer's project M3, also orange, and with a special striped paint job. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Being the sister website to Automobile Magazine allows us front-row seats to a rotating selection of the latest vehicles. Since we share a building, their fleet of vehicles is literally right outside our windows. We have noticed the infusion of candy colors into the recent lineup of vehicles, and frankly, we love it.

When a 2013 BMW M3 coupe—one of a limited set of 200 Lime Rock Park edition cars—arrived in fiery orange, we took notice. We quickly snapped a photo of Jean showing her love for this sweet piece of citrus and posted it on our Facebook page. Her love ran so deep that she was inspired to infuse new orange items into her wardrobe (notice the shoes at right). When Jon Seizinger of Center BMW in Sherman Oaks, California, spotted our post on Facebook, he shared photos about a project car that his dealership has created. The dealership's 2011 E90 M3 is modified to increase performance and illustrate to customers ways that their dealership can tweak M-series cars. In spite of the modifications, the project M3 is still covered under a standard four-year/50,000-mile warranty and is eligible for complimentary maintenance.

Paint Stripes as Homage

The part of the project that truly interested me was the paint treatment. Seizinger shared the attention to detail that went into the paint scheme. "The stripes on the car were hand painted by a local pinstripe artist here [in California]. The colors are traditional BMW M-series colors and were hand applied using different brushes and techniques. We wanted each stripe to have an individual character and feel to it, much like we wanted our car to have. We wanted to evoke the passion of something created by hand in the same way a painting is painted or a sculpture is sculpted. Not temporary and cheap like [a] vinyl sticker. It also pays homage to the way racing stripes were hand applied with brushes in the early days of racing and speed records.” In a nutshell, the car looks like it should be parked in your living room to show what great taste you have in art. Take a look at their videos.

Fun on Campus

Here in Ann Arbor, I took advantage of the opportunity to take our M3 for a quick zip around town. I was pleased to find that the steering wheel is covered in Alcantara; as JKC readers may remember, I have compared it to flannel for the hands. The double-clutch automatic transmission with paddle shifters made driving this performance monster more like driving a pussycat. I was glad not to be grinding gears accidentally as I maneuvered around the student pedestrians on the University of Michigan campus. I attracted quite a bit of attention from the students, who usually don’t seem to notice that I exist. I wasn’t sure if it was because of my new haircut or the color of this little whip. It could also have been the engine growl as I played with the paddle shifters.
The ride was a little harsh on the badly potholed spring roads, and I imagined how sweet it would be to take a few laps on the ultra-smooth Lime Rock track instead.

The BMW-Lime Rock Connection

The M3 I was driving is a joint project of BMW and Skip Barber, the Lime Rock Park owner and racing-school magnate. This is the first time Lime Rock has partnered with any manufacturer. The model we drove is priced at $80,295, but since it is one of only 200, it stands to reason that each one will be snatched up quickly.

As Michigan struggles its way into spring, it lifts our spirits to see something bright outside. But the new candy-colored paint jobs that I am seeing increasingly on the road made me wonder: would I get sick of the attention that a bright orange car would garner? What about driving around in a car that was festooned with an outrageous paint job?

images.caption: Center BMW's M3
Stripes are individually painted.
Center BMW's Jon Seizinger says the stripes are all traditional BMW M colors.
Meanwhile, back in Ann Arbor, Jean got new shoes and brought out the orange sweater.

title: Tesla Model S: 100 Heading to Vegas
subTitle: Will this idea change life in cities?
promoTitle: Tesla Model S: 100 Heading to Vegas
promoTeaserSmall: Will this idea change life in cities?
promoTeaser: Would you get rid of your car if you knew you had 100 Tesla Model S electric cars at your disposal?
keywords: Tesla Model S: 100 Heading to Vegas
metaTitle: Tesla Model S: 100 Heading to Vegas - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Tesla Model S: 100 Heading to Vegas
metaDescription: Tesla Model S: 100 Heading to Vegas. Read about an ambitious venture to bring 100 Tesla Model S electric cars and a host of other transportation choices to the city of Las Vegas. The idea is to get people to give up personal cars and build closer interpersonal relationships. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Would you give up your car if you had 100 Teslas on standby?

It might seem odd to go out and buy 100 cars when your aim is to get people to give up cars, but things are different in Las Vegas. Project 100, part of the larger Downtown Project, has just signed an agreement to buy 100 Tesla Model S electric cars that will be available for people to use in the city on an as-needed basis.
Personally, I might find the “need” pretty often if I were one of the limited number of dues-paying members who will get the opportunity to get into a Model S.

It’s all part of an ambitious urban improvement project in the neon capital of the world.  A group of visionaries have plans that range from a social center made out of storage crates, to be populated by art galleries and cafes, to downtown speaker series and family events. Their aim is to get people to gather and connect by making it easier to move around in the city. They say wonky things like, “we see an opportunity to hack density,” and “[we’re] working to increase collisions between people.”
But not collisions between Teslas, naturally. The catch to this scheme is that you don’t get to drive the Model S, only to be chauffeured in it by a paid driver.

Here’s How It Works

Here’s the plan. You sign up to be part of the Project 100 “complete transportation system.” Like all the best new tech, it’s in beta and is invitation only for the next few months. Once a member, you download a mobile app and then you can order up what you need to get around. There will be 100-plus “on demand drivers,” 100-plus shared cars, 100-plus shared bicycles, and 100-plus shared shuttle bus stops, all available for the approximately $400-a-month membership fee.

The choices will be: be picked up by a driver in a Tesla within three minutes, walk up to two-tenths of a mile to drive yourself in a much less pricey low-range electric vehicle such as a Polaris GEM, borrow a bicycle, or take a “party bus” that will be stopping every four minutes around the city.

Project 100 is structuring the plan around a series of urban zones. Charging stations will be based around the downtown area, and the logistics of getting people to vehicles and vehicles to people will be a complex algorithm that the group is working on now.

Who’s Behind It?

If you like buying shoes from Zappos, you probably know that the founder, Nick Swinmurn, started really small. I mean, really small. He started out just snapping pictures of shoes from retail stores, posting them online, and offering to buy and ship them to a small customer base. The scheme turned out pretty well for the company, now headed by CEO Tony Hsieh. And Hsieh has now turned his attention to the urban revitalization problem, and with his track record of turning ideas into gold, it just might work.

So you can’t imagine riding a bicycle over to the casino? These people want Las Vegas to be more than that. Would you give up your car if the infrastructure for transportation were easy enough to use?

pageElements.text: I’ve been racking up to 100,000 miles a year since my late teenage years, when I was a taxicab owner/operator. There is nothing I love to do more than to teach kids the driving secrets I’ve learned over the miles. Damn. I wish had me around when I was their age. I would have told me how stupid it was to drive everywhere at 100 miles an hour. I would have learned emergency maneuvers long before I actually had to make one.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/r6ogQcBbPUU" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Of course, there is nothing like, oh, a few million or so miles behind the wheel, with a chunk of that at high speed on a racetrack, to give you a tad of well-earned confidence behind the wheel.
At least I learned how to drive a stick before I saw my first automatic.

So here I am, ready to serve. This isn’t a comprehensive driver’s ed class. I’m aiming with the No. 1 Ladies' Driving Academy to share the things I’ve learned wayyy outside the classroom. I want kids to know as many different ways as possible of getting out of trouble on the road. Like, say, avoiding it altogether.
I will keep making these videos as long as there are kids (and don’t take that Ladies thing seriously; boys Я allowed) with new questions about how to do whatever it is they are afraid of doing.
Ask and you will receive.

Love,
Jean

contributors.bio:
I don’t understand people who dislike driving. I really don't. The freedom of getting behind the wheel of a car and just taking off can't be compared with anything else. You really feel that you’re in charge: in charge of the car, in charge of the road, and in charge of your life. Why on earth would you want someone else to drive you around when you could do it yourself? It’s so liberating! Obviously, I love driving. I suppose that isn't a particularly original statement for a Detroit native, but it's true. I was a little late getting my driver's license because of that pesky parallel parking, but once I got it, nothing could stop me. It doesn't matter if I have to chauffeur my grandmother to the bank less than a block from our house or drive across town. If I have my green Chrysler LHS--affectionately christened "Betsy" by my mother--and some gas in the tank, and if I am somehow able to avoid getting pulled over for driving just a little too fast, I'm good to go.

Since I graduated from the University of Michigan, in April 2012, Betsy has taken me everywhere. She has been my steadfast companion on trips to buy more supplies for various sewing projects, leisurely drives along Jefferson/Lakeshore Drive in Grosse Pointe Shores, Michigan, and frequent jaunts to the bookstore to buy yet another copy of Hamlet, a 500-plus-page book on Elizabeth I, or a good book on British history that isn’t as dry as a piece of chalk…And, yes, there is a little bit of theme there. Not only am I a bibliophile, but I’m also a self-proclaimed Anglophile who loves Shakespeare and Elizabethan verse and one day plans to see the Houses of Parliament, visit the Tower of London, and, perhaps most important, eat real fish and chips. If only I could drive Betsy "across the pond…"

pageElements.text: If you’re planning on taking a road trip or two this summer, there’s something Volkswagen wants you to download before you load everything into the car.

Volkswagen's free Smileage app will be out this summer for Android phones only. Co-developed with Google, it's a fresh, funny way to track and share your adventures behind the wheel. The term "smileage" is the automaker's way of signaling that it's all about the fun factor. Using the app, you can document and share experiences on the road whether you drive a VW or not.

Slug Bugs, and Much More

Just sync the app with your car, and from then on it will automatically connect and track your driving route while running in the background. For every drive you take while connected, the app will give you a trip summary and add up your Smileage score.

Using your Google contacts list, you can let friends watch and comment on your travels in real time. Increase your Smileage number by sharing more information, tagging friends who are in the car with you, posting photos, and sharing comments.

Shorter trips, like your commute to work, will most likely trigger lower Smileage ratings than more adventurous weekend drives. For longer trips, you can choose to use Smileage in trip mode, which will add your trip photos and videos to an interactive map that records your route. Friends can experience your travels with you and comment on them in real time.

You knew there was a Slug Bug angle, and there is: every time your car passes another one that’s also using the Smileage app, you get a virtual badge that shows a punching hand. You can also earn virtual stickers like this twins icon (right), indicating you’ve passed a VW that’s just the same as yours. Sounds like fun!

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: If you’ve been thinking about heading to Dubai for a high-speed jaunt in your multi-hundred-thousand-dollar supercar, leaving the police shaking their fists in your trail of dust as their underpowered PPVs are easily outrun by your V-12 engine, think again. Dubai’s fuzz have their own V-12s now, and they’re not afraid to use them.

The desert city’s police force announced in mid-April that they would be adding a Lamborghini Aventador to their patrol fleet, presumably to intimidate drivers who are looking to take advantage of the area’s open desert highways to verify top speed on their expensive sports cars.

Two weeks ago during an event at one of Dubai’s shopping malls, Dubai police first announced that a Lamborghini Aventador with a 691 horsepower, 6.5-liter V-12 engine and a top speed of 217 mph would be added to the fleet. The Aventador will be joined by a Ferrari FF, a four-wheel-drive Ferrari with a 6.3-liter V-12 engine that produces 651 horsepower and can also crest 200 mph. In addition to those confirmed additions to the force’s stable, there are now reports that a Bentley Continental GT and a Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG are being added to the fleet, too.

Those reports—unconfirmed by the police force—stem from leaked photos that show a Continental and an SLS sitting in a garage. While we all wait with bated breath to hear if Dubai’s speeders will have two more ultra-fast police vehicles on their hands, we can contemplate the reasoning behind the announcement that the Ferrari FF will be reserved for Dubai’s female police officers.

No word on what makes women particularly suited for Ferraris, but I can’t say  that I’d turn down the offer to spend my work day behind the wheel of an FF with a legitimate, legal excuse to drive it really, really fast.

pageElements.text: Today at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, as April ends and the racing world prepares to turn its attention to the Brickyard, the track is being put to a very different purpose: a nice 2.5-mile walk around the oval featuring 5,000 or more dogs and their human friends.

We love dogs at Jean Knows Cars, so we were fascinated to learn that the Humane Society of Indianapolis’s major fundraiser is one where people can take their dogs out to the world-famous track and walk around it together. It’s happening today, Saturday, April 27, and the participating individuals and teams are hearing the announcement, “Ladies and gentlemen, start your paws” over the loudspeaker.
Who wouldn’t want the opportunity to walk the track, even if it weren’t for such a good cause?

We’ve got one thing to say: Next year in Indianapolis! We’re already mentally putting together our team of dogs and friends. Plan to join us in 2014! Meanwhile, the people at IndyHumane will be happy to take your donation online right now and send you an Indy Mutt Strut T-shirt.

pageElements.text:
2013 Nissan Quest 3.5 LE


Vital Stats

Pricing: The Quest 3.5 LE is the top-of-the-line model and reflects a $16,650 premium over the base 2013 Quest 3.5 S. The base 2013 Quest 3.5 S starts at $26,815, including destination. All of the Quest models are equipped with the same powertrain, a 3.5-liter V-6 engine linked to a continuously variable transmission. This Quest is priced at $43,675, including shipping, and includes one option: $210 carpeted floor mats for all rows.
EPA fuel economy: 19 mpg city/25 mpg highway. The 2013 Chrysler Town & Country with a 3.6-liter V-6 and six-speed automatic transmission returns 17/25 mpg, the 2013 Honda Odyssey with 3.5-liter V-6 and six-speed automatic transmission returns 19/28 mpg, and the 2013 Toyota Sienna with a 3.5-liter V-6 and six-speed automatic transmission returns 18/25 mpg.
Standard safety features: Six airbags, stability control, traction control, child safety rear door locks. This LE also includes standard Around View monitor and advanced blind-spot warning (via a warning indicator light on side mirrors). Both are new for 2013.
Chief competitors: Honda Odyssey (top EX-L Touring Elite is $44,855), Toyota Sienna (top Limited model is $45,055), Chrysler Town & Country (top Limited model is $41,740)
<iframe width="420" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/T3rB7HRZWuM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

- Sorry, Quest. The 2014 Honda Odyssey Touring Elite just introduced a major minivan game changer with the first-ever built-in vacuum in a minivan.
- Nissan has aimed the Quest at “the woman behind the mom.” During a media presentation in 2004, it flashed a picture of Marion Cunningham, the sweet but frumpy mom on the old TV sitcom Happy Days, with a slash across her face, and said the Quest isn't for women like her.
- The Quest has been set apart as the radical design alternative in the minivan category.
- Let’s talk practicality. If your family is large, the Quest only seats seven passengers. The Odyssey and Sienna (depending on trim level) can seat up to eight.
- Quest also has less cargo capacity than most of its rivals.
- On the plus side, Quest has a modern, upscale and sophisticated cabin and a relative rarity among minivans – a standard push-button start. The LE model also includes a thirteen-speaker Bose sound system, a third-row power return seatback, and a DVD entertainment system. (The DVD system is standard on this model but a $2,100 option on other Quest models; buyers will also pay $1,350 extra for a dual-opening glass moonroof, available only on SL and LE models.)
- Rear visibility from the driver’s seat is not great.
- Some entertainment and climate controls are blocked by the gearshift lever.
- Smooth ride, but it tends to lean in corners (may cause carsickness in some kids!).
- Six cupholders and six bottle holders. Sienna has twelve cupholders, plus front and rear door map pockets with bottle holders. The top-of-the-line Odyssey Touring Elite has total of fifteen beverage holders.

pageElements.text: We’ve been enamored of the 2014 Corvette Stingray ever since we first laid eyes on it at the Detroit Auto Show in January, but details on the target of our affection have been sketchy. We know it looks good. We know it’s powerful. But how much will it cost to make it ours? Last week, Chevrolet finally announced the numbers on the Stingray, and they’re not as bad as you might think.

The seventh-generation Corvette will be available as a coupe or a convertible. The coupe will start at $51,995, and the convertible will start at $56,995 (both prices include destination). That relatively small sum won’t get you the fastest, fanciest Corvette, but it will get you a 6.2-liter V-8 engine, the most powerful base engine in a Corvette ever, that produces 450 horsepower and 450 pound-feet of torque. You’ll also get two eight-inch information/entertainment displays with a rear-view camera and MyLink radio, weight-reducing carbon fiber body panels, and a nine-speaker Bose sound system with satellite radio, Bluetooth capability, and USB and auxiliary input jacks, among other features.

If the standard features seem a little sparse for you, never fear. Chevrolet will offer plenty of à la carte options to fill out your Stingray. The carmaker has helpfully suggested a list of major available options–including a performance package that helps launch the Vette to 60 mph in less than four seconds, an $8,005 leather-wrapped interior, Magnetic Ride Control with Performance Traction Management, and several other cosmetic upgrades. That package would bump the price of a Stingray coupe to $73,360.

pageElements.text: Say you’ve got a serious love for biking but don’t love the hassle of getting your bike from your house to the trails—what are your options for transporting your two-wheeler? It’s the conundrum of urban-dwelling outdoor enthusiasts and weekend-warrior triathletes everywhere. We’re here with a few tips to help your car and your bike get along like old friends.

Roof Rack?

Roof racks are standard equipment for seasonal sport lovers from skiers to kayakers, and bikers are no exception. They’re not universal, so you’ll have to put a little effort into finding one that fits your vehicle. On the bright side, you will be able to fit several bikes on top of your car and won’t have to compromise on interior cargo space.

Standby brands Thule and Yakima have guides on their websites that will point you toward the right rack for your car. You’ll likely have to buy mounts and crossbars before you buy the attachment to fit a bike, so buying a roof rack can end up costing several hundred dollars. But once you’ve got a roof rack, you can buy attachments to carry all kinds of gear, so you won’t have to pay for a whole new setup to switch from carrying bikes to carrying snowboards.

Rear Bike Rack?

If your problem with roof racks is that they’re too high off the ground for you to work with, but you’re not fundamentally opposed to strapping bikes to the outside of your car, a rear bike rack could be the answer. These essentially come in two flavors: the cheap universal kind that you strap to the trunk, and the more expensive, more durable hitch-mounted carriers. In both cases, your bikes will be easier to load and unload than when using a roof rack.

Trunk-mounted carriers are less of a commitment than hitch-mounted setups, but since they attach directly to a car’s body panels, they can cause paint damage. Their nylon straps aren’t terribly durable, either (and can be easily sliced by bike-jackers). Hitch-mounted carriers require a vehicle with a towing hitch and are more expensive than the trunk-mounted variety, but they also tend to be sturdier and easier to load. Both types of carriers can be purchased to handle multiple bikes.

Hatchback or Giant SUV?

If you’re really committed to easy bike transport, you can look for a car that will fit bikes in the cargo hold comfortably. Admittedly, this narrows your vehicle choices somewhat, but owning a car with ample cargo space can be useful even when your bike isn’t along for the ride. Large SUVs or vans are the obvious choice for transporting bikes, but hatchbacks can have just as much cargo space with the seats down, can get better fuel economy, and are typically cheaper than full-size SUVs. Transporting a bike inside your vehicle can offer a little more security from theft or damage and won’t affect your car’s ability to go through a drive-through the way a loaded roof rack can.
What’s your preferred method of bike transportation? Let us know in the comments below.

pageElements.text: You are headed for Miami Beach: the land of the well tanned, the opulent, and the Art Deco style. You have decided that for this occasion, you’d like to play dressup in a vehicle that doesn’t quite fit your everyday persona. You’ve spotted the Mercedes-Benz G63 AMG in pictures, but the shimmery white exterior on your model strikes you as particularly well suited to the South Beach strip along Collins Avenue, where the regular work week feels nonexistent and the traffic crawls along with a constant “look at me” exclamation on a Wednesday afternoon.

Mercedes-Benz calls this shade Arctic White, but you think it should be called Fourteen-Carat Diamond, with all the sparkle in the sunshine. Some would opt for a convertible in South Beach, but you think that’s passé. The point is to be both exclusive and inaccessible, and the G63 fills the bill. Admit it: the G63’s speedy and powerful AMG package makes you want to play. The more outrageous, the better, you sing to yourself as you prepare to pull away in the hefty sport-utility vehicle, which costs a pretty $135,000 penny.

Hoist yourself up high into the black-leather cockpit and gaze down at the cars below. You’ve got an impressive list of technology at your fingertips, including mbrace2, the Mercedes-Benz concierge and assistance system. Crank the sonically superior Harman Kardon Logic 7 surround sound system, preferably to a satellite station with some sort of constant bass as a theme, and let the engine growl. In case anyone asks you what you’re working with, tell him your ride is equipped with a 5.5-liter biturbo engine that makes a whopping 535 horsepower.

But a word of caution: don’t bring up the gas mileage on the G63 AMG. Your guilty pleasure averages 12 mpg in the city. Ouch! But don’t worry—you don’t need to drive long or far to make your point. And luckily for you, you don’t have to test out the rain-sensing intermittent windshield wipers, either. There’s not a cloud in the sky as you open the sliding sunroof. You mean serious beach business.

pageElements.text: When Ford and SHFT.com previewed their new app, Food Tripping, for Earth Day 2013, the dinner party was held at The Leadbelly in New York City. The seasonal spread included a wide selection of East Coast oysters, a farm-to-table family-style meal, and biodynamic wines. The small establishment, tucked into the narrow side streets of lower Manhattan, is one of those cool neighborhood spots that you’d never find except by word of mouth or an app.

And that’s just what Food Tripping is all about. The app, available for use on iPhones, iPads, and Android phones, allows users to find a range of fresh, local, seasonal, and healthy food options on the go. The free app has a database of over 100,000 “good food” restaurants, farmers’ markets, juice bars, organic grocery stores, and more across the United States.

Sustainability Stars Are Behind the App

Film producer Peter Glatzer and actor/filmmaker Adrian Grenier founded SHFT.com in December 2009. “Our mission is to nudge sustainable ideas and designs into pop culture, and to provide context for an inspiring and sustainable way of life,” explained Glatzer.

Inspiring, yes. The site, which has won two Webby awards, is a colorful conglomerate of clever content that covers everything from art and architecture to fashion and food. The filmmakers have incorporated a mix of well-produced videos and The Big SHFT, an original series about innovators in sustainability, produced in partnership with Ford.

“Sustainability is the biggest issue facing business in the twenty-first century, and the problem will not be solved by one person or group,” said Ford Motor Company executive chairman Bill Ford. "How we answer the challenge of the future of mobility will have a lasting impact on generations to come. By partnering with organizations like SHFT, we are able to inspire people to make smart decisions about the products they choose today.”
In fact, Bill Ford believed in SHFT so much that he joined its board, joining other great minds that include Richard Branson and Arianna Huffington.

“Ford is a huge game changer for us,” said Glatzer. “This is just one example of how Ford has put their money and their commitment to bringing options to people who are looking for alternatives to the norm. Ford has a phrase, ‘the power of choice,’ and SHFT is about showing people options.”

What Can You Find with It?

The Food Tripping app, Glatzer said, "is about focusing on all of the smaller hidden gems around the country…anything from vegan markets to organic wineries, cheese makers, dairies, or microbrewers.”

Grenier, who lives in New York City, added: “Food is one of the best gateways to a bigger lifestyle change. We are all about showcasing things in a way that is inspiring and titillating." To create a broader base of inspiring food options, Food Tripping is looking to users to populate the app with their own favorite food places around the country.

“SHFT has been 100 million percent rewarding. I feel that I am doing something that matters,” says the well-known actor, who starred on HBO’s Entourage. “I can act and create entertainment and prance around like a movie star, but what’s the takeaway? This kind of work is extremely satisfying [to the] body, mind and soul.”
Glatzer commented: “We don’t want to be activists, elitist or crunchy.  We just want to live better. We are just guys that created a platform that anyone can access.”

How It Works

Food Tripping, available for free for iPhone, iPad, and Android, is a fun format that's super easy to use. First, open the app and click on your current location. Next, browse through a list of healthy categories: eateries, farmers’ markets, food markets, coffee and tea, juice joints and smoothies, vegan and vegetarian, drink artisans, and food artisans.

After selecting your choices, the app will present you with a well-designed map and list of places with addresses and phone numbers. There are also buttons for suggestions, favorite places, and names of businesses if you want to get more specific. I looked up the name "Jean" and came up with sustainable eateries located in Florida and Missouri. Then, just for the heck of it, I looked up "McDonald’s." No results!

How Can You Get It?

Food Tripping will be available late 2013 in the Ford Sync system, but until then, you can download it from the SHFT website.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: It’s the age-old story of car technology: what starts as an expensive option only available in luxury cars becomes standard equipment after a few years on the market. It happened with CD players, navigation systems, and power windows, and now it’s happening with four-door passive entry. Sexy, right?

The Chevrolet Malibu LTZ—a car for the everyperson, starting at $28,175 including destination—has four-door passive entry available as an option in the $1,000 LTZ Premium package. The technology allows drivers to unlock all four doors and the trunk without fussing with the key fob.

Just Get within Three Feet and Presto!

When the Malibu’s closed-loop wireless communication system verifies that the correct key fob is within three feet of the car, the driver door can be unlocked by pressing the button on the door handle once. A second press will unlock the rest of the doors and the trunk. Malibu engineers originally toyed with the idea of having the car unlock automatically when it sensed that the key was nearby but decided against that system to avoid accidentally unlocking the car every time you pass it.

Chevrolet hopes the technology will make life just a touch easier for Malibu owners. If you’ve ever fumbled with the keys while wrangling the kids or hauling an armful of shopping bags, you know that this could just be one of the seemingly minor technology upgrades that you end up deciding you can’t live without.
